reviewText:
A nice, relaxing game to play when you're bored.

The Puzzles become gradually more challenging and there are almost 20 of them.

For people who like puzzling I can recommend that game.
Unfortunately the mouse-click-handling often behaves very unexpected, so that instead of picking the exact puzzle piece you're clicking on it picks another one which actually was drawn below the one you clicked on.

But puzzles are games which require a lot of patience anyway, so I guess that shouldn't be too bad.
Oh and yeah, as I've read in other reviews, there's actually no save-feature... so you need to finish a puzzle in one session.

(Also it doesn't even remember the settings you chose in the options menu, e.g. volume, fullscreen, etc.)

Just a simple, relaxing jigsaw puzzle game with images inspired by Japan.  There isn't much to complain about, except that there are not a lot of puzzles.  They start out easy, and when you finish enoug, you unlock the tougher puzzles.  The puzzle shapes are highly unusual.  It's a decent time-waster.
All you need is strong fingers.
Cool, and very acient graphic to me.

Do you like jigsaw puzzles?
Do you like difficult jigsaw puzzles, with areas of the same colour (i.e. the sky)?
Do you like Japanese style art?

If yes they this game is you you, as that is what it delivers, and does it well.

If no, then you may not enjoy this game.

I purchased this game on sale and I only recommend this game when it's on sale.

In all honesty, I've never been so irritated playing a game since the last time I've played League of Legends. Let me describe to you what is so irritating. The play area is made up of a table which you assemble the puzzle pieces on and there's a river/pool along the left and top edge of the screen that the unused pieces float around in. Now in the early levels where there's less pieces and the pieces are larger this pool is fine and works great. However, when you progress and the pieces become smaller and more of them it's almost impossible to click on the piece you need. The majority of the time spent on this game has been trying to click on a piece I need and picking up pieces that my cursor isn't even touching. I wish this game wasn't digital so I could flip the table over.

Now if you can get passed the irritating pool the game is fine and enjoyable. It's a jigsaw puzzle game. You piece the puzzle together and you complete the puzzle. It's as simple as that and done well in that regard.
Jigsaw puzzles you don't have to clean up or glue together!

A jigsaw puzzle is this thing where you have all these little pieces and you put them together to form a whole, often featuring a design such as pictures of famous people like David Hasselhoff, or others. Sometimes the pieces get lost and you can't complete the jigsaw puzzle. That's when the OCD rage starts to boil, and the fires of hell are loosed upon the unsuspecting masses. Also sometimes someone nice gives you candy, but don't take the candy because the candy isn't really free. Nothing is free. But this game doesn't have pictures of David Hasselhoff for some reason, just Japanese landmarks and stuff. Also in this game you can shove a fish into a bamboo pipe.\n\nJigsaw fish pipe.

This is a great puzzle game for all the puzzle lovers out there! The music can get a bit repetetive after a while, but it's quite calming. Good pictures with increasingly harder puzzles. If you can get it for a dollar or two its well worth your money.

Fun and relaxing game, have yet to advance to the more complex puzzles were the sheer number of pieces may get messy, but i like it so far. Its on sale now so i'd get it especially if you are like me and had no jigsaw puzzle game.

A very nice game with magnificent images from Japan. Nice ambient music and sounds, and of course newly added achievements for the hunters out there. It is a little bit of addictive, so do not forget to take your eyes away from the screen once in a while. Also prepare for a lot of rage explosions while trying to pick the piece you want but you pick all the other ones … but the one you actually want. Great puzzle (literally) game over all. Do recommend.

I love this game! It's a jigsaw puzzle very neatly and conveniently on your computer. If you can't sleep, especially with too much on your mind, this game is good medicine. Please don't think from that description that this is boring.  The puzzles get more\nand more difficult and you can't quit in the middle of a puzzle, you must finish or give up. I wish I could buy ten more of this type.

I'd recommend this game for folks who love puzzles but are short on space, have cats, or for some other reason are unable to pull out a 1000+ piece puzzle to assemble. To fully enjoy the game, players should probably also like games that require catching something that is moving with a click of the controller...or fishing games. There are, however, a few points that could be polished up:

- The mouse pointer is not very accurate and sometimes sluggish.
- The game lacks a true working space to organize selected puzzle pieces. (If you accidentally put the right piece in the right place on the board the piece will lock down, so it's a bit risky - and un-fun - to only have the puzzle board to place various fished-out pieces.)
- You can catch the koi...but it does nothing.
- There's no save option. Be prepared to have enough time to complete the puzzle when you sit down to play (most don't take *that* long) or to leave the game running in the background when something comes up.
- The speed of the flow in the puzzle piece pond" is not adjustable. When combined with mouse accuracy issues

Since there's really not that much to say about jigsaw puzzle games in general, this review will be a summary of pros and cons, accompanied with brief commentary by me.

Pros
-piece edges diversity: all puzzles have pieces with their own distinct edges (the interlocking bulges / notches), which rather give an original feeling to each puzzle.
-audio: soothing Japanese background tune and sound effects
-achievements: easy to accomplish a perfect game (100% achievements), only time and patience required, little skill.

Cons
-no save game option: can be a nuisance especially on the larger of the puzzles; several times i had to leave the game running until I got time again to complete a puzzle.
-no player accounts: 1 player only, bit of a pity, since I’m father in a family of 4 gaming people, who want to track their progress separately.
-amount of puzzles / smaller puzzles: there are 21 puzzles (6x60pcs / 5x112pcs / 4x153pcs / 3x220pcs / 1x350pcs / 2 additional puzzles of 153pcs (i think)); which is too few
-hard to grab desired pieces from the pond: it's hard to precisely grab the piece you want from the pond, hard in such a way I’m wondering the developers have done this deliberately.
-audio: only 1 background tune

In short:
Pixel Puzzles: Japan is a soothing, little jigsaw puzzle game with little functionality. Would be better with more and larger puzzles, combined with a save game option. Picked it up at a sale (<€1), completed approximately 2 puzzles / week. Took my time enjoying puzzling. Perfected the game (100% achievements) in 17 hours and moved on. Probably never replaying Pixel Puzzles: Japan again, since there are other Pixel Puzzles versions on the market I want to complete. When my desire to puzzle comes back, that is.

Greetings and have fun

Bad  points : The game has only 21 jigsaw puzzles so far by now (19 achievements and 2 in addition), which can be completed in 5 hours more or less. There is no save option so you will always have to leave the computer on while you want to take a pause from completing a puzzle. There is no zooming option which makes 200 plus pieces puzzles difficult. Another problem comes from the fish pond where you'll have quite a hard time trying to catch the piece that you want. There is no option to puzzelize your own images from the computer nor a way to add other jigsaw puzzles other than waiting for an update.\nGood points : The game is light and fast even on pretty old machines, thou sometimes it crashes without other programs open. The fish and the fountain can be both forgotten when you'll put one into the other XD so you'll not catch it anymore while searching your piece thou it's kinda sad seeing it there...poor fish. There are nice song pieces that change often, so if you'll not like a specific song, you'll have to wait just a while and it's gone. Since they are pieces, it also contributes to the light weight of the game. You can mute the songs if you really dislike them. In the extras there are the photos of the puzzles, so be sure to check it before attempting to complete a puzzle. The images are kinda tricky with many similar colors this makes the puzzles fun, not to mention that they are wonderful. If you'll find the images too difficult for you, the anchor system of the pieces will come handy for you, thou it is a bit too sensible. The pond idea with the pieces floating in it is also nice but if you can get rid of the fish, you cannot do the same with the flowers and pieces can hide under them, like when they stuck in a corner... kinda tricky. Overall it's really nice, also because you can repeat the puzzles that you want, or force yourself by deleting the data and starting all over.

reviewText:
Shorthand:

If you dig jigsaw puzzles and the game happens to be on sale, I totally reccommend it.

Longish-winded:

Pixel Puzzles Japan is relatively low-fuss fun. Its atmosphere is intentionally relaxing, its puzzle piece shapes vary to keep the player's eyes active and interested from puzzle to puzzle, and its lack of timer and continuous achievements allow players to feel accomplished without being rushed. While the game is far from perfect, vulnerable to minor click-and-drag inconsistencies and the occasional piece getting stuck beneath already completed sections, its theme and its ever-moving, ever-calm background make any momentary frustration just that: momentary. Likewise, the non-puzzle art isn't perfect either, but what it lacks in polish it makes up for in charm. 7/10.

Music is a nice calm pase is great for completing the puzzles, if you are into puzzles this one is for you.

-Several puzzles Styles.
-Achievements.
-Puzzles Unlocks.
For me this was rather a great game game to relax and forget how many times i died in hotline miami 2 ;)

But puzzles are games which require a lot of patience anyway, so I guess that shouldn't be too bad.
Oh and yeah, as I've read in other reviews, there's actually no save-feature... so you need to finish a puzzle in one session.

(Also it doesn't even remember the settings you chose in the options menu, e.g. volume, fullscreen, etc.)

Those bits got me hypnoticed !\n\n10/10

A nice atmospheric jigsaw puzzle game. It has its share of drawbacks, though:
1) Taking a piece out of the koi pond may be frustrating and their movement is confusing;
2) Puzzle pieces are bound to the board - you can randomly drop a piece on its right place, but you can't connect them before that. Kinda silly, but doesn't really ruin the experience.

I got it for free on indiegala giveaway, so I'm not sure if It's worth its price. But I enjoyed it and I'm sure other people who like jigsaw puzzles will do as well.

reviewText: Good game for puzzle lovers !

Finally done.

This is old-fashioned puzzle game with Japan theme. For me, the gameplay is fun. But, it makes me bored sometime because the floating part of puzzles are so many out there. You will face many shapes of it (from large to small size) and it is very difficult for the first time. At least, there is a traditional Japan music (tell me if I am wrong!) so I can relax a while when I am solving the puzzle. You will know the structure of puzzles at the end.

One thing, I don't understand why there is a Koi fish and we should put it to stop the popping water from the bamboo. I don't know.

Should I recommend this game?
Yes, I should. If you are a puzzle lover, I would recommend to grab this game. The price of game is cheap too.
In the past, an organization gave the key of this game for free.

I love Japan, I like the beautiful scenery of Japan, I like the historical building of Japan.
Thanks to the Monk, now I am your follower.

Here’s something I never thought I’d say: I actually rather enjoyed Pixel Puzzles: Japan.

Aside from the rapid onset of carpal tunnel, this game wasn’t terrible. I’m not sure if it was situational when I played it (at nights while staying oceanfront) or if the game is actually acceptable but I had fun. In fact, considering I paid nothing for it, the only real flaw I saw was that god forsaken river the pieces floated in. Oh my god I have never been so annoyed by anything in a game before. And don’t even get me started on the “zen” water pipe thing. Word of advice: Immediately stuff that stupid koi in there and shut it up. Also why on earth are we not allowed to save progress on a puzzle and come back to it later?

I guess the game is kinda crap.. but I didn’t spend a penny on it and I had fun, so yeah take from that what you will.
This is a puzzle game, not anything more nor less. But a satisfying one.

So kawaii! Need I say more? In all seriousness, I love this game! It's challenging enough (At least for me), has a wonderfully calming soundtrack, and beautiful Japanese pictures. I haven't completed all puzzles yet, but I am looking forward to doing so ^-^

reviewText: Just your average puzzle game with strange cool puzzle pieces 7/10 needs more puzzles.

Pixel Puzzles: Japan is a casual jigsaw game. It is the first jigsaw puzzle game on Steam and it is relaxing and fun.

The gameplay is simple and self explenatory, just like in the original board game you have to fit together puzzle pieces to form a beautiful japanese scenery. There are 19 different puzzles, ranging from ones with 60 pieces to one with 350 pieces. Each puzzle in this game has a different picture but also the puzzle pieces differ as well. This game offers an unique experience since some of the puzzles have pieces with shapes that you won't see in real life. Unlike in real life you can see the image of the puzzle you are working on just before starting the level. There is a power-up that fills up and shows the original picture for a few seconds if used. There is no time or objectives, so the game is very relaxing and you have nothing to worry about. Also, there is a fish swimming in the river that you can play with, for fun. On the other hand, there are some disadvantages of this game. There is no save feature mid puzzle so if you leave a puzzle you have to start it over. That is a big problem in the last levels since they take a lot of time to finish so your only option is to leave your PC open. Another flaw is selecting the pieces you want. The puzzle pieces float around a river around the ''table''. That is a good ideea, but when you try to click on the piece you want you will probably end up selecting another piece and having to put it back into the river and sometimes the piece you want disappears into another point of the river.

The graphics are pretty nice and the japanese pictures very beautiful. The music is relaxing just as the gameplay.

I recommend this game, casual, relaxing and fun, 8/10.

At least, there is a traditional Japan music (tell me if I am wrong!) so I can relax a while when I am solving the puzzle. You will know the structure of puzzles at the end.

One thing, I don't understand why there is a Koi fish and we should put it to stop the popping water from the bamboo. I don't know.

Should I recommend this game?
Yes, I should. If you are a puzzle lover, I would recommend to grab this game. The price of game is cheap too.

Maybe at first sight this game looks a bit boring or simple, but trust me, if you start playing it, you'll just want to play it more!
After a long day, this can really help you to relieve stress and anger.
The music from the game is really calm and it's refreshing for the soul.

There were some annoying things, which aren't that bad, but I'll list them here:
When you select a puzzle piece, it randomly picks another one, even if there is a larger space between the pieces.
The game doesn't remember settings like Full screen/Windowes mode after you exit the game.
And advertising on the main menu for other puzzle game from the developer(s).
Maybe that last one, isn't so noticable and not everyone has an issue with it, but I didn't really liked it.

So my final score for the game is a:
9.5/10

-Great game and if you have some change in your wallet, grab this little game and have fun with it!
Nice if you want achievements ;)

The first game in the Pixel Puzzles series that I played. It delivers the jigsaw puzzle experience that you'd expect (imagine).  It's okay, there's not much to say about it. Rotating pieces is not possible, they are always in the correct orientation - I have no issue with this. There is some sort of hint system, but I haven't used it very much at all. Instead, there is a delightful exploit that efficiently helps with the more aggravating, end-game pictures. One minor annoyance is that you cannot enjoy a moment with the picture you just completed, as there is immediately a popup on top of it.

After 9.1 hours I finally did all of the puzzles!
Honestly what can you expect from a puzzle game.
Music is relaxing
Pieces floating around can get kind of annoying
Fast and easy achievements
Don't have to clean up all the dang pieces like you do in real life
Saving your progress is kind of iffy

At least you are not trying to jam pieces where they dont belong

6.5/10

Nice and relaxing puzzle game. Sometimes it goes more annoying than relaxing though, when you can't pick up the puzzle pieces properly. But I enjoyed it none the less.

If you are a fan of jigsaw puzzles, you will enjoy this game. Some levels really hard to complete and it takes time. But there is a few annoying things:\nOnly one music theme through all game. After the third level it bores. And level's environment all the same.\nIt is impossible to pick up piece of puzzle you need when you play 100+ pieces levels. Doesn't matter how hard you aim, you will pick up everything (even fish) but not the piece, which needed.Hope these things have been reworked in other games of Pixel Puzzles series.

This game is simplicity to the extreme; all you do is put puzzles together. However, the puzzles are beautiful and they slowly get harder (more pieces) the more you complete. Music is wonderful and fits very nicely to the relaxing atmosphere. For a casual game fix, this is a definite pick. 9/10. Worth the money.

It's fun and casual enough, but one major frustration: SELECTING PIECES.
- they move! Make them static and let us sort them ourselves.
- click a piece, and youll select the bottom / random piece near the mouse cursor snapping
- any settings such as sound, fullscreen, background are not saved.

If I hadn't gotten the game for free, I'd never have gotten it, simple as that.

Edit, i'm going to have to go and change this from recommend to not recommend. The click selection is RIDICULOUSLY bad to the point of frustration, especially at the later levels, there are so many pieces, all moving, and you can not for lack of trying select a specific piece!

This game is as simple as it sounds. You put together digital jigsaw puzzles in the theme of Japanese locations and nature settings. The difficulty steadily increases with increasingly complex images and higher piece-counts until you reach the end. The later puzzles initially seemed as if they could take forever but I could tell that there was some type of subtle assist in place, as I too often would find the piece I needed when the situation should have been like a needle-in-a-haystack. Probably because of limited screen real estate making it too complex to play completely true-to-life. No matter, the game is enjoyable and plenty relaxing. The sounds are naturally fairly soothing but i also enjoyed listening to some albums while I played and collected the achievements.

[ENG / FR]

[ENG]

Pixel Puzzles: Japan offers 19 unlockable puzzles with the following distribution:
6x60 bits / 5x112 bits / 4x153 bits / 3x220 bits / 1x350 bits
What can we expect in such a game?

+ Pictures depict pretty well japanese culture and landscapes
+ Unusual shape of the bits in some of the puzzles
+ Well measured progressive difficulty
+ Well thought help system
+ Left bits shuffling option
+ Set color change option
+ Steam cards and achievements

- No save system (If you leave a puzzle you will have to restart it from the beginning)
- Retouched pictures, some of them are a little bit blurred
- Only one track in the sountrack which ends up to be repetitive
- Drudgery of the bit pickup system, especially in the medium range puzzles

Pixel Puzzles: Japan is a nice game for any puzzle enthusiast and for who knows how to be patient.
Thanks to its pretty and wide pictures it can allow you to have quiet and resting times, if you are indulgent enough with the soundtrack on the long run.
The help system deserves a good point: it permits to see the full picture for a few seconds while emptying a gauge you will refill with a correct bits placement on the set.
An option to let us decide if we want the bits to spawn in the right direction or not would have been nice (They all spawn in the right direction, you don't have to rotate them).

Be aware that the bit pickup system can quickly become irritating in the medium difficulties. Let me explain.
During a game all the available bits float around the game set and you just have to click on it to select one.
This isn't embarrassing during the first 60 bits puzzles because the space around the set isn't overloaded yet.
However this can become a real pain with the rising of the bits number and you will have to click many times before eventually catching the one bit you want.

Furthermore the game portrays us as a meditating monk whose senses are expanding through your overall progression.
Therefore as soon as the number of bits increases significantly it becomes nearly impossible to pick the desired bit because of the monk not being awaken" enough.
This problem will solve itself once every puzzle would have been unlocked. The monk will then become fully "awaken" and it will be much more easy to catch the chosen bit.

To sum it up once again
date:
it is a nice little game but that will require patience from you.

▬

reviewText:
A jigsaw puzzle game where you can't do many of the things you would likely do when putting together a physical jigsaw puzzle.

First off, when tweaking with the options setting such as changing from fullscreen to window (no resolution options available), music, and sound effects, none of the settings stay the same when you start the game up again; you'd have to retweak all that stuff to their desired place. The options menu itself doesn't really contain all that much anyway.

Puzzle pieces can't be rotated but are apparently already turned the right way so there'd be no need for that.

You can't piece together matching jigsaw puzzles; each individual piece can only be snapped on the canvas where they belong even if there are no other pieces around. This means that you can basically grab a puzzle piece and keep dragging & dropping the thing all over the canvas, if desired, until it snaps into the place where it's apparently supposed to go.

The puzzle pieces you're supposed to grab outside of the canvas don't stay still; they slowly float about on a pond outside of the field bouncing from walls, a few sometimes get stuck on a wall and just stay still for whatever reason. It becomes more of a bother than a challenge (if it's even supposed to be a challenge of some kind) since the pieces will always overlap one another, so way too likely you won't always grab the puzzle piece you want even if the mouse is on the desired piece. This is much worse later on when the pieces become smaller and higher in number. You can drag the puzzle pieces out of the pond to the canvas but that's more than likely to just block the view of the canvas itself with clutter.

If you were to leave a puzzle-in-progress it doesn't save and there's no option to. If you need to exit the game you'd have to start whatever puzzle you were doing all over again.

I was hoping this jigsaw puzzle game was more of the things I'd do with a pyshical one and not just a game where I just drag piece (A) to point (B) with the addition of technical nuisances.
For all of you puzzle masters try this,really good game,not ordinary puzzle game @.@

This game is perfect for when you want to chill out with some Netflix streaming on one monitor and some achievements from jigsaw puzzles on your other monitor (you have two screens, too, right?). If they ever add more puzzles I'll be all over it like white on rice. If you're into jigsaw puzzles and need to keep yourself busy while you consume other media then this is perfect for you!

reviewText: I enjoyed most of the puzzles but without a save option, I doubt that I will put in the energy to complete the last three which have hundreds of tiny pieces all floating in the pond.  Picking up pieces is frustrating because if any pieces besides the one you wanted is nearby, you will probably pick that one up.   Puzzles are normally leisurely activities where you can place a few pieces down at a time. Forced to complete a puzzle in one sitting is not relaxing.

reviewText:
For the memory of the Jigsaw-Mania in the 70s
I remember the time quite well, when my cousins an me got a box of Jigsaws each birthday and x-mas... It was during the early 70s, and Jigsaws were all the rage...

I think just because of this I am still so deeply fascinated by puzzle games of any color...

Of course, this is a computer rendition of that time and as the original it is all about zen... Jigsaws are superficially very simple games of search and stack, the end product is on the cover of the box. This game captures a lot of this style, and it's all about Japan in this game. With a lot of beautiful sceneries and a fitting sound. Even a priceless Koi is swimming in the pond in which all the puzzle parts are floating.

Can you wish for more, dear puzzler?

Indeed you could, but that would probably take away the charm of the game at all. It's simple, it's as fast as you wish it to be and it is quite fun when you remember that this kind of game are casual games. Not to be played in one session, but when you need that kind of relaxation.

I would recomend this game for the sceneries, the calmness and medative quality it has and because it is an emulation of the original Jigsaws, that still can keep people peeled to the solution, even if it takes weeks to solve.

Have fun playing the game.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText: The puzzle pieces move in this game which isn't bad but sometimes they are hard to pick up and put on the board. The trick to this game is to put all the puzzle pieces in a pill on the board and then pick up each piece and somehow it will come out in order and make the puzzles a little easier. The achievements were easy to get, pretty much you complete the puzzles, and play around with the one fish by putting it on the board and into the thing that drops water at the bottom left of the screen. Great game, I recommend this to puzzle lovers and people with patience

reviewText:
Pixel Puzzles: Japan is a jigsaw puzzle simulation game. It is said to have some light gameplay elemtns mixed in with putting together jigsaw puzzles. Putting together puzzles without all the mess of getting the pieces out, making sure you get them facing up, clearing the space to put it together, and then putting it away later is nice. The actual act of putting the pieces into the puzzle is fun. Some other virtual puzzles I've done are far too forgiving on how close you need to put the pieces, but this game does a good job of making you put it in the right place before it'll stick without it being too horribly specific to make you second guess yourself constantly. Some of these puzzles were fun to put together with neat pictures as a result. Also, there were some interesting edges and piece shapes which gave the different puzzles a little life and challenge to put together. The jigsaw puzzle part is good. My issues come in when you're looking at the gameplay elements that have been included to spice the game up. Either these elements should be eliminated, or there needs to be more of the elements.

The elements that are there are mostly annoying or useless. Being able to pick up a fish and move it around isn't really challenging or fun, it's just useless. Completing puzzles to unlock more is also a bit useless, as anyone doing this for the sake of doing the puzzles is going to do them all anyway so having them all available to pick from would be nice. Plus, leveling up for completing puzzles just to unlock other puzzles is also fairly useless in the grand scheme of things if the only reason for them is to play more of the game you were most likely going to play more of anyway. The annoying part is how the puzzle pieces are stuck in a pool of water around the corner the table. So the pieces will freely float around, covering each other up and bouncing around, which makes them difficult to sift through. There's also an annoying priority going on. See, they have somewhat of an order. Pieces go from top left to top right, then down a row starting on the left again, and so on. So if you click in an area that would select multiple pieces, whichever one is highest on that priority list will be picked up, even if you clicked mostly on a different piece or didn't want that one. Also, if you drop a piece back in the water it, along with any other pieces it lands on, will sink and respawn in a spot in the water on the left. So the constant movement, piece priority, and sinking situation all make for a very frustrating puzzle experience. There's not really any penalty for these things. It just takes longer and is more frustrating. It wastes your own time and tries your patience, whch I don't think is a good reason to have the elements. The only useful element is that, once you get enough pieces in, you can click on the sun and reveal the entire picture for a few seconds to refresh your memory... even though most people would be able to look at it the while time when doing a real puzzle.

On the other hand, there could be MORE elements and it'd make the game more fun, or at least have it make more sense. For instance, maybe something with time. A time limit, or just a timer to record your time. Some type of score for using the piece you grab and taking points away for throwing a piece back. Reasons to go faster and be more precise, plus giving a point to the tedious design. Getting better ranks to unlock perks or just to unlock puzzles. Having online leaderboards to compete for scores or times with others. There are plenty of things that could be added to make the current model of the game make more sense and possibly make it more enjoyable as a video game. Even just a save feature would be nice. In real life, many people will take breaks from big puzzles. Without a save feature, you can't do that here unless you want to leave your game running the entire time, which not everyone wants to do.

A few of the puzzles were made up of similar looking things to the point of resorting to random placement to find where anything went. Maybe my eyes just suck, but they were not fun as trial and error challenges. Like the one with all the flowers... my word. Also, most of the puzzles look rather similar to each other anyway, which makes some sense with the common theme of Japan, but I still think more variety could've been had. I only found a few of the pictures interesting to look at and try to solve.

What I'm saying is that Pixel Puzzles: Japan falls just a bit short of being a good puzzle simulation, and falls very short of being a fun interactive gaming experience. There needs to be more or less features to make this work well either way, at least for my taste. I played all the way through it, aside from the bonus puzzles. I got all the achievements and did all the main puzzles. I was very worn out near the middle but kept on going to see if it got any different. It really didn't. This game was ten hours of the same thing that, despite doing more puzzles and being a decent amount of puzzles for the price, wasn't a fun experience towards the last half. Changing the elements would make it better and possibly could've made me enjoy this game as a whole. However, I just can't say I enjoyed it. The first few puzzles were fun, but it gets old fast. I got this for free and... as mean as it sounds, I still feel like it was a waste. At least the last half was a waste of my time as I didn't enjoy it, but I wanted to review it and give it a fair chance for reviewing purposes. I feel I've done that, and I honestly cannot recommend it as is, especially at the 7 dollar asking price. Pixel Puzzles: Japan gets a 3/10 for having potential to be a good puzzle simulation or puzzle video game, but failing to do much justice to either camp.

reviewText:
It's quite amazing that a game about putting together jigsaw puzzles with a zen theme manages to be such a stressful experience.

It makes me wonder if the developers ever played with an actual puzzle, as most of the staples of it (ie, looking for patterns among the pieces, setting apart groups of them that seem like they go together, seeing where they fit with the whole picture, leaving the puzzle and going back to it later, etc) are just not possible in this game. Forget about going for specific pieces; you can click all you want on the piece that caught your eye, the game will still give you the piece it thinks you deserve instead. Since they're constantly moving, you'll helplessly watch them drift away from you over and over. The pieces do not `click`, with each other, they just snap to their place on the main grid. So much space on the screen is wasted with useless graphics and blank space that could have been used for much needed game space. The lack of a quick save is a big flaw as well.

The pictures are alright, if a bit uninspired and the shapes of the pieces are all nice and varied. The sounds are fine, but they do get grating after a while, especially since it's always the same, over and over.

The game is still playable, and you'll barely notice its flaws in the smaller puzzles, but it's all uphill from there. I managed to finish it, but that's mainly because I'm an achievement junkie, more than anything else.

Easy Achievements
Nice Japanese music
Casual puzzle game

reviewText:
Does this one fit here? Nope. This one? Nope. How about this one? Nope. This? No. That? No. That one over there? NOPE! ...and this one? N.O.P.E. .... THIS ONE MUST BE THE CORRECT ONE. NOPE!

They said puzzles were fun and relaxing. Well... they were wrong. This games becomes tiresome and boring fast. You have to complete the puzzle in one go. You can't resume half-done puzzle. reviewText:
Complete Opposite of a peaceful relaxing game and traditional jigsaw puzzle approach.....

I like jigsaw puzzles, but like a previous review mentioned, it goes against all the fundamentals of jigsaw puzzles.

TL;DR Can't build 'sections' of the puzzle, mouse aiming is terrible, with 'bomb' affect when dropping piece, enjoy seriously fishing for pieces. No saving

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

1. You cannot connect pieces together that you know should fit to make sections. This game makes you pretty much work from the sides and then crawl from there. You might think well isn't that is how people do puzzles? Yes, but when you do these, when you see other pieces can join up with each other, you can start piecing them together and save them aside for the bigger picture. This game does not allow to do so. The way it works is that pieces will only 'fit' on the board if they are on the eaxact location, so if you were really bored.... you could grab each piece click drop over the board till u find it locked in place.........

2. Mouse aiming. Terrible in this game, you end up half the time picking up other pieces instead of the one you want. If you then, proceed to drop this piece ontop of your desired piece, then enjoy searching for it again from the spawn pool as for some odd reason they decided to add an effect which pretty much makes the dropped piece bomb the other pieces as well to make them disappear. The HD" graphics don't even feel HD at all.... more like low res and the scaled up... Hell.... MSN jigsaw puzzles where more HD than this.....

3. Floating pieces
date: I didn't mind it at the start but then it got annoying. Each time you pick a piece
recommended: you can drop it back in the water and it disappears and goes back to the 'spawn point'. At first it was nice
hoursPlayed: but with the terrible mouse aiming

helpfulPercent: because then all the other pieces you dropped will just reappear there).\n\n4. No save?! Forced to play the whole puzzle until completion? Alright...... I don't see that happening with other jigsaw puzzles I do..... I don't see some elf scrambling the whole board at night to wake up to see my puzzle reset."

reviewText:
Little Disclaimer: I got this game in a bundle, so I didn't buy full price for it. I wouldn't recommend anyone to buy this game at full price.

The reason is rather simple: This game fails on almost every level.
It is supposed to be a jigsaw puzzle game, yet the engine is seriously flawed:
You cannot attach pieces to each other even if you know they fit. You can only fix them to their final position. This makes it kind of" easy to solve every puzzle: Choose a position
date: drag every puzzle piece to that position until one fits. Rinse and repeat.\nWhen several pieces are on top of each other
recommended: it seem to be pure randomness which one is selected by clicking. It may be the bottom-most one. It never is "the one visible that I want to click". Sometimes you have to shovel several pieces away from one position to finally select the one you want.\nThe "pond" is a nice idea
hoursPlayed: it's implementation however heavily collides with the idea of a relaxing jigsaw puzzle game. Instead of having a quiet atmosphear
voteText: there always is something moving. The form of the pond (at least on my resolution) results in pieces cluttering on one side of the screen. As all pieces swim

The kai was disturbing as well but at least that could be removed (see achievements). The other puzzle game from the developers hints that they have a very strange idea about what relaxing jigsaw puzzle games should look like...\nThere is no area to sort pieces. When for real puzzles

votesFunny: here. You might consider using the pond but every piece thrown into the pond changes location. Not only does it flow away over time; it immediately is put to a random place when dropped. This also is very frustrating when "digging" for a single piece by throwing everything else back into the pond: You easily throw away the desired piece on accident and then it's hard to find again.\nI've played freeware puzzle games that allowed to customize the puzzles (choose your own picture
commentsCount: choose number of pieces). This game does not support any of this. When even the addition of new puzzles is worth an update post

For jigsaw puzzle lover, do not buy it. Save you time and money.

reviewText: As someone who loves doing physical jigsaw puzzles, I looked forward to digging into this game. While it is a gorgeous aesthetic, the shifting flow of pieces around the board was incredibly annoying to me. I organize my physical puzzles by color and the inability to have any organization or structure made the game much less enjoyable. Plus it was very difficult to selevt what piece you wanted. While the music was good, there is only one track while you're working on puzzles and one track while in the menu as I recall, and that gets incredibly repetitive when you're spending 20+ minutes on a puzzle. There are also only 19 puzzles, and I finished this game in a couple days. I would really give this game a neutral rating if that was an choice, but with how grating the music was and the incessant annoyance of finding the piece I wanted, I had to go with the negative option.

reviewText:
Pixel Puzzles: Japan is a couple of terrible projecting misconceptions, leading to creation of playable game - but only if you are really obstinate to complete it.
This game is a typical jigsaw puzzle, rarely found on steam (if not unique). It includes around 20 different images. As suggested, all of them are japanese-themed. So, you complete puzzles, and by this you level up this tiny monk in bottom-left corner, from acolyte to someone who looks as if was abducted by aliens. Higher monk levels unlock more challenging puzzles, and he levels up when you complete all but one pictures from tier. Actual game is simple: pick piece from the pond and move it to right location, where it will be automatically locked. While regular jigsaw puzzles allow you to see the complete picture - here it's a bonus. You unlock a glance at the picture by placing pieces in correct locations. Unfortunately - even in the biggest puzzles you can use it 2-3 times.
Stated at the beginning - this game is a collection of terrible projecting misconceptions. Firstly - while not a problem at smaller puzzles, try picking specified piece on more difficult ones. It's literally impossible. If the pieces are in swarm (and in this tiny pond they are almost all the time), game picks not the one you selected, but one closer to left top corner (this leads to exploit - check guides at game hub for more info on this). Second thing that bothered me terribly - game settings restart after you turn off the game. It's pain in the butt - mute the game (as the soundtrack and effects are quite annoying) everytime you play. Finally, due to limited access to big picture - some puzzles have to be completed by trying to fit each piece in every place (like in picture with cherry blooms).
To sum up, this game is a great example of production with wasted potential. Jigsaw puzzles are scarce on Steam, so it's a shame that game like this is done so badly. Good things? If you try really hard, you may have fun. Plus, achievements are pretty easy to get - completing the game gives you all of them.

reviewText:
TL;DR: A fine jigsaw puzzle game that however gets irritating later on because of the lack of saving feature and unreliable jigsaw piece catching.

Pixel Puzzles presents one of the simplest forms of puzzles, jigsaw puzzles, now ported from real life to computer screen. As you'd expect by the subtitle, the theme is Japan. This shows itself both in the puzzles themselves and the interface.

In the interface there's a metagame of you being some kind of a Buddhist guru who levels up and becomes ever more enlightened as you solve more puzzles. The puzzles are at first quite easy (i.e. few pieces) but as you get more enlightened" more difficult (i.e. larger) puzzles are unlocked.

Puzzle pictures look good and usually contain various temples
recommended: cherry trees and castles from the classic Land of the Rising Sun - you won't find anime girls
hoursPlayed: video game references or weird game shows here
voteText: IMO rather unfortunately actually as it would have introduced more variety. Instead
helpfulPercent:
all is serene and beautiful and the music is somewhat relaxing mix in a traditional Japanese style. I frankly muted it after a while and listened to my own music because it was making me sleepy.

Gameplay is the important part. The jigsaw pieces are floating in a pond next to the puzzle table and you have to pick them up with mouse cursor. It's sometimes difficult to pick the one you want as the pieces can float over each other and for some reason the one you are pointing with mouse might not be the one picked up - that's rather annoying especially in the larger puzzles where the pieces are smaller.

Obviously some simplifications have been taken in the design. The pieces are of fixed orientation
votesHelpful: so they never need to be rotated. They also lock in place if you drop them close enough to the intended spot. You also can't see the whole picture but before the puzzle and after gaining enough "insight" (i.e. completing large enough part of the puzzle) and then only for a short time. As a minor note
votesTotal: the pieces on the board obscure what's underneath
votesFunny: and once you are close to finishing they might be camouflaged in within the puzzle pattern and there's no way to highlight them for easy notice.\n\nIn my opinion the major flaw of the game is the lack of saving feature: once you have started a puzzle
commentsCount: you need to complete it or start over again later. This is especially frustrating for the largest puzzles (300-350 pieces) of the end-game as they can take an hour or more to complete. Actually 8 hours of my game time was accumulated when I cracked and left the game running for the night to finish the halfway done last puzzle I started the previous night.\n\nOverall I didn't enjoy it very much

reviewText:
I'm a big fan of jigsaw puzzles, and I was excited when I recieved this as a gift. Now... I really hate to write negative reviews, as I try to look at the effort and love that were put in to games. But sometimes there are just games that I can't give a positive review to. And sadly? This is one of them.

=Complete Review= (TL:DR version and Conclusion at the bottom)


=The Gameplay: 2/5= It's rather mediocre, in terms of gameplay. Puzzle pieces snap in place when placed on their correct spot on the grid, which would be better if the pieces snapped to eachother instead... But I can understand developer-wise why they wouldn't do that, due to the fact it would be a bit of a hassle if a player put a combined-piece back in to the pond. And, it's still better than the pieces not snapping in to place at all.

Speaking of the pond, it's probably a big player in the game's issues. It would be fine if it only moved the pieces around, that's a bit annoying, but I get what they were trying to do. But because of the pieces moving around, it makes picking up pieces just flat out annoying because of it sometimes glitching up pieces. You'll try to pick up a edge piece, and wind up picking up a piece that's practically another whole piece away.  Half the time I just move all the pieces from the pond on to the board, just so that way I can pick them up right.

The powerup in the game is also... Strange. I only used it once so I could see how it worked. It changes the background to show the rest of the image so you'll know where to put the pieces, but personally I found it more fun to just put the puzzle together without it.

And the koi, don't get me started on the koi. Just don't... About the best part involving the koi is sticking it in the sozu. I'd say that's a redeeming feature, as the bloody fish got in my way a number of times when picking up puzzle pieces. But some people would likely just find that cruel, so it's a your-mileage-may-vary thing.


=The Graphics: 3/5= Now this, is a redeeming feature of the game. The graphics look  nice in my opinion! The UI is done well, the actual images for the puzzles are of good quality, the pieces having different unique designs to mix things up in the more difficult levels. It's quite asthetically pleasing!

But it's not to the level that would be considered eyecatching, and breathtaking. Well done, but not embellished much. Which, well, that's good or bad, depending on your preferences. For the concept, a simpler style does work well. But for those wanting a more ornate, and intricate looking style, this would likely not be all that pleasing to the eye for them.


=The Audio: 1/5=  Ugh.. Now this is the part I absolutely hated. It was fine for maybe the first two puzzles. But the music with the haphazard sound effects tossed in just doesn't work... I mean, sure, the sound effects fit the theme, sort of. But the mixed volumes of the sound effects and the music would be more prone to cause tension as opposed to relaxation. Which, is what the theme aims for: a zen-style.

I personally muted it and played more relaxing tunes to it. I'd suggest that you pick your favorite zen or relaxing music and turn that on instead if you play this.


=TL;DR/Pros & Cons=

Pros
A pretty pleasing jigsaw puzzle game.
Has achievements that are fairly easy to get.
The pictures are lovely.

Neutral
You get to put the koi in the sozu.
The graphics are pretty simple.
Puzzle pieces snap to the frame rather than to eachother.

Cons
The game is a bit glitchy because of the bloody pond.
The music and sfx are terrible IMO.
Your progress on the puzzles are not saved.


=The Conclusion: 4/10=
It's a decent game if it's on a sale above 75%, but if not, it's definitely not worth the full price. It was a cute idea, but the execution was not done very well. I've played much better jigsaw puzzle games for free, of which I'd link, but that would be in poor taste. A quick google search of Flash Jigsaw Puzzle" should come up with some.

I appreciate your time
date: and thank you for reading my review."

reviewText:
Pixel Puzzles: Japan is a fun puzzle game with motives from Japan. In my opinion they have choosen really good pictures for their puzzles.
Before this game, I played Pixel Puzzles 2: Anime and really enjoyed it, so I was looking forward to this game.
And I wasn't disappointed. But still, there are a few things, I disliked.
But since this game was released BEFORE -Pixel Puzzles 2: Anime- I can forgive the missing features.
The two things that I really missed were:
1. The Puzzle Pieces were in the right direction all the time, so you don’t have to spin them, to see where they can fit. (Not that tragic)
2. You can’t save while doing a puzzle.
In Pixel Puzzles 2: Anime the games saves by itself, you can start with a puzzle, close the game and progress further with it when you got time. This feature is completely missing here.
If you start with a Puzzle, you have to finish it. If you close the game, you have to start over with the current puzzle. Kind of annoying at the later Puzzles.

Still, I recommend the game.
The motives are nice, The Puzzles are fun. Every Puzzle has its own unique pieces. So you have to look for something else in every game.

If you’re looking for a good, fun and relaxing Puzzle game, you will not regret buying it.
Still, if you only want one puzzle game and like anime-style puzzles, I would go for Pixel Puzzles 2: Anime, alone for the comfortable save option.

reviewText:
The game isn't bad, but it's definitely not great. For being a game that is supposed to be 'zen', it has some features that make it pretty frustrating, particularly when doing puzzles with more pieces. At first, the game starts out being pretty relaxing, but as the game continues, the pieces floating around get smaller and smaller. This makes it hard to see what's on them sometimes, but that wouldn't be a problem in itself.

The main problem is that once there gets to be more pieces, it's incredibly difficult to get the piece you actually want, especially before it floats under another clump of pieces. Even if the piece is on top, it feels like more often than not, whenever you click, it will select a random piece from within a centimeter or so radius. And forget about just dropping the piece and trying again - when you drop a piece, it takes itself and all the pieces around it back to the single spawn point in the water for the pieces. Soon, all the pieces will be all clustered together there and you'll basically just need to pile all the pieces up on your playing board if you want any of them, espeically a specific one.

It would be nice to be able to actually select only the piece you are clicking on. It would also be very helpful not to have a piece go back to the spawn point when setting it down and have it actually stay where you set it. The ability to turn off the floating of the pieces would also be useful, particularly once they get pretty small.

Another feature that this game is lacking that I've seen on free puzzle games is the ability for pieces to 'stick' to their neighboring pieces. Basically in this game, pieces only lock into place on the actual board. Even if you find two pieces that obviously go together but don't know where to put them yet, they will stay as separate pieces. It would be really nice if the pieces could click together and then be moved together. Maybe the developers didn't want to include this feature on purpose and I could see where having large chunks of pieces already stuck together would clutter up the board, but maybe it could be a feature that players could choose to turn on or off.

Despite these annoying flaws, the game still does have some pros, including nice pictures and pretty neat edge styles that vary from puzzle to puzzle. It is a fun game, but it would be a lot less of a headache with the addition of the features I mentioned earlier. Because of the problems and the shortness of the game, I would have to NOT recomend the game at it's full price - $7 is too much when there are plenty of free puzzle games on other sites. If the game is ever on sale for $4 or less, then I would recommend picking it up if you're interested.

reviewText:
This could have been a decent game to kill time and relax but a huge flaw with the controls ruins the experience entirely.

The game has a decent variety of pictures and difficulty, the layout is clean and adequate. The smallest puzzles can be done in ten minutes while the bigger ones can take up to a few hours. The music is relatively bland but a lot of players will use their own music anyway so it doesn't really matter.

Some features clearly show that the dev team has a lack of understanding about jigsaw puzzles. To begin with, and although it can seem soothing, having the pieces move around in a pond is a really bad idea considering most people who play such puzzles like to organize their pieces, or at least remember approximately where some of them were. Additionally, it would have been nice to have a small picture of the completed puzzle somewhere in the layout, as a reference. It could be argued that not having it adds to the difficulty but the point of jigsaw puzzles has never been to recreate a picture that you saw during three seconds before starting to play.

That being said, those two flaws are incredibly minor compared to the main problem of the game: when there are a lot of pieces in the pond, the cursor detection to grab them is incredibly bad. It's so bad that you really wonder if they actually tested it. To be clear, it's not like you misclick from time to time and grab a piece you didn't want. I literally had to click twenty times on some pieces to get the one I wanted. I even gave up on some of them because they were floating among too many other pieces. Sometimes, even with no piece in a close proximity, you still end up with the wrong piece grabbed. In a way, it's quite amazing to witness. You could even laugh it off if it didn't happen every five seconds. This should have been a game to relax and this flaw alone makes it incredibly infuriating during the long puzzles.

I only beat this game out of spite.

reviewText:
Most of my favorite games are action packed shooters filled with explosions and many different guns and complex role playing games with tons of story and dialog to become immersed in. So why do I recommend this game? For one point really: it's highly relaxing.

Sometimes I want to just sit back, relax, and enjoy a game and maybe work my brain a little too. This game does just that. I got this game for free over at the IndieGala website, and when I first downloaded it, I didn't expect to like it at all, but I was completely wrong.

I load up this game after a long day at school or doing homework for hours on end. It's a great way to escape stress and just let go. Most games I play require my full attention and for me to constantly be doing something. With no timer, Pixel Puzzles: Japan lets to solve beautiful puzzles centered around famous Japanese monuments and landscapes at your own pace.

While the game is fairly simplistic, there are a few minor complaints. The first would be the higher level puzzles. As you progress, puzzle pieces become more and more strange. They're not your ordinary jigsaw pieces anymore, they're abstractly cut and hard to piece together. One way you can solve this is by starting with the sides and corners first.

Second, and it is a small minor complaint, but I don't like how the pieces float around so much. I understand that they move around to make you have to look for them more, but I wish it was just a little bit slower.

Anyways, I recommend this game to anyone looking for a relaxing and simple game to help take stress away from their lives. Sit back, grab a nice beverage and enjoy this wonderful little title, Pixel Puzzles: Japan.

reviewText:
القرآن)، ولا تتم الصلاة (وعبادات أخرى) في الإسلام إلا بإتقان بعض العربية هي أيضاً لغة شعائرية رئيسية لدى عدد من الكنائس المسيحية في الوطن العربي، كما كتبت بها الكثير من أهم الأعمال الدينية والفكرية اليهودية في العصور الوسطى. وأثّر انتشار الإسلام، وتأسيسه دولاً، في ارتفاع مكانة اللغة العربية، وأصبحت لغة السياسة والعلم والأدب لقرون طويلة في الأراضي التي حكمها المسلمون، وأثرت العربية تأثيراً مباشراً أو غير مباشر على كثير من اللغات الأخرى في العالم الإسلامي، كالتركية والفارسية والأمازيغية والكردية والأردوية والماليزية والإندونيسية والألبانية وبعض اللغات الإفريقية الأخرى مثل الهاوسا والسواحيلية والتجرية والأمهرية و الصومالية، وبعض اللغات الأوروبية وخاصةً المتوسطية كالإسبانية والبرتغالية والمالطية والصقلية، كما أنها تُدرَّس بشكل رسمي أو غير رسمي في الدول الإسلامية والدول الإفريقية المحاذية للوطن العربي.
العربية لغة رسمية في كل دول الوطن العربي إضافة إلى كونها لغة رسمية في تشاد وإريتريا وإسرائيل. وهي إحدى اللغات الرسمية الست في منظمة الأمم المتحدة، ويُحتفل باليوم العالمي للغة العربية في يسمبركذكراعتماد العربية بين لغات العمل في الأمم المد
واللغة العربية من أغزر اللغات من حيث المادة اللغوية، فعلى سبيل المثال يحوي معجم لسان العرب لابن منظور من القرن الثالث عشر أكثر من ألف مادة، بينما في اللغة الإنجليزية فإن قاموس صموئيل جونسون وهو من أوائل من وضع قاموساً إنجليزياً من القرن الثامن عشر يحتوي على ألف كلم
تحتوي العربية على حرفاً مكتوباً. ويرى بعض اللغويين أنه يجب إضافة حرف الهمزة إلى حروف العربية، ليصبح عدد الحرو تُكتب العربية من اليمين إلى اليسار - ومثلها اللغة الفارسية والعبرية وعلى عكس الكثير من اللغات العالمية - ومن أعلى الصفحة إلى أسفلها.
العربية هي أيضاً لغة شعائرية رئيسية لدى عدد من الكنائس المسيحية في الوطن العربي، كما كتبت بها الكثير العربية هي أيضاً لغة شعائرية رئيسية لدى عدد من الكنائس المسيحية في الوطن العربي، كما كتبت بها الكثير العربية هي أيضاً لغة شعائرية رئيسية لدى عدد من الكنائس المسيحية في الوطن العربي، كما كتبت بها الكثير

reviewText:
First impression of this game was very good. Nice puzzles. But after a while the controls are getting really annoying. The pieces are floating around the board and are constantly overlapping each other. This won't be a big problem if there are few pieces. But while you progress the pieces per puzzle are increasing, but not the space where they are floating around.
In the last puzzles I couldn't pick a specific piece but got a random piece.

Sadly there are some bugs. For example when you pick up a piece and drop it on another piece the will reset all to a spawn point". Too bad if you teleport your piece away which you tried to reach.

Another bug apears
date: when the pieces are floating around for a while. Especially when there are a huge amount of pieces. The get stuck. This sound nice
recommended:
because you might pick them up easier. But they also stack while the are stuck. So you might not find your missing piece ;)

Too bad you can't turn off the floating.

A level editor to add own images would be nice. And if the pieces wouldn't be oriented correctly would give a new challenge to the puzzles. But only if you can pick up the piece you want to.

Due to the bugs and frustration I only recommend it to you if you are patient.

5/10"

reviewText:
This game doesn't manage to ruin the fun of putting jigsaw puzzles together, but it comes close with some terrible design choices:

- When you place a piece in the correct spot, it locks in place... even if it's not connected to any neighboring pieces and it was just dump luck that you placed it there. This really kills your feeling of actually having any skill. There's also no visual indicator of which pieces are locked in their correct position, and which still need to be placed.

- Pieces are ALWAYS oriented correctly with the puzzle. They never rotate.

- If you find matching pieces, but don't know where they fit on the board yet, you can't keep them snapped together. You can't even put them beside each other somewhere out of the way, because there IS no out of the way" area.

- All the loose pieces move around in a koi pond beside the puzzle. You can take pieces out of the pond
date: but the only place to put them is on the puzzle board itself.\n\n- You can't just look at the box to see what the finished puzzle looks like. You have to correctly place a bunch of pieces to earn a five second glimpse of the finished puzzle."

reviewText:
Pixel Puzzles is exactly what it looks like: a jigsaw puzzle game.  Unused pieces float around the top and left of the puzzle in an appropriately-themed koi pond until you grab them and place them in the puzzle.  All pieces are oriented correctly with no rotation function.  Pieces will lock into place when close enough to their correct location no matter if adjacent pieces are in place or not.  Pieces will not lock together when not already placed in the correct location in the puzzle.

Puzzles increase in difficulty as you progress through the game by increasing the complexity of the image and the number of pieces in the puzzle.  In the later puzzles the pond is so packed with pieces it's very difficult to locate a specific one and I took to just dragging random pieces out onto the board.  Each puzzle has different shapes for pieces and some of them make it very obvious when two pieces fit together.

There is one large problem with the game however.  When picking up pieces, the game has a really nasty habit of picking up any piece EXCEPT the one you actually clicked on.  I've clicked on a piece that was completely alone in the pond and had the game grab one an inch away instead.  It gets quite frustrating seeing a piece and not being able to grab it before it floats off to get lost in the jumble of other pieces again.

Despite that one major flaw, it's a competent jigsaw puzzle game which I don't believe there are many of on Steam.  I'd rate it an indifferent" if I could."

reviewText:
All puzzles completed, including DLC to date.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=269499644

Pixel Puzzles is a nice jig-saw simulator. It has a wide range of puzzles with pastoral scenes of rural to ancient Japan that individually range from ho-hum to downright beautiful. The puzzles go from 'easy' 60pieces to what I would call 'journeyman' 250pieces.

The setting is weirdly enough chinese... As you solve a puzzle, a chinese monk is pondering the I-ching and as you successfully place the pieces of your puzzle, he achieves enlightenment which gives you the chance to tap into this enlightenment to see a representation of the completed puzzle.

The puzzle difficulty is tiered and you only unlock the next tier by levelling up your monk which you achieve by completing a set number of puzzles in a given tier. The way it is set up gives the impression that you can go your own way, but the only freedom you have is by deciding which puzzle in a tier you want to do first.

The puzzle-screen is workmanlike and efficient, which I like. The screen's layout successfully focuses your attention to the part where you work on your puzzle. There's no information on the screen that can grab your attention away from the puzzle. No weird animated stuff, no dancing gibbies, no unasked for anime-crap (which the developers could easily have fallen for, I admire their restraint.).

The music is light and unintrusive, though I must echo the complaints about the waterdrip garden-ornament. I never experienced the old sound-effect as it was patched before I bought Pixel Puzzles: Japan, but it still serves to shatter my concentration now and then. I would like to see an option to disable/enable the waterdrip garden-ornament so that players who don't want the sound-effect can play the game without it.

Bordering the puzzle-table is a koi-pond in which the pieces float around. I guess the idea is that the player is rummaging around in there with their hands to grab a piece. I think it's a fun idea, but it doesn't translate well once in the game and trying to fish out the piece that you want can be a source of mild annoyance.
Though the developers did went the extra mile here. For a cute laugh, catch the Koi and drop it on the puzzle-table. ^^

The actual completing of the jig-saws is fundamentally flawed though. The pieces don't snap together, but they individually snap to the grid. This means that you can't make clusters like you can when you piece together a real jig-saw. I think that this is a glaring oversight.
Secondly, it makes it extremely easy to cheese completion of a jig-saw as you can move a random piece around until it snaps in place, made even easier because the snap-to-grid mechanic is very forgiving. I have oftenly seen that I pushed a random piece aside only to have it snap to the grid!
Another thing that missed the intended goal I guess is the form of the pieces. Though the developers probably thought that the sometimes outlandish shapes would make the puzzles harder, (did they recognize the problem with the snap-to-grid action too?), it actually achieves the opposite. I oftenly found myself looking for a specific shape rather than trying to find a piece that graphically matched the picture. The weird shapes make it too easy to piece together the bane of every jig-saw fanatic; large sections of clear blue sky.

There is no scoring in Pixel Puzzles so completing a puzzle without using the monk's enlightenment goes unrewarded. Pixel Puzzles further does not block the computer from falling asleep, or to start the screensaver. Pixel Puzzler also doesn't believe in tooltips so it isn't readily clear what a button does unless you click on it to find out.

While I do like the game an sich, as it does exactly what it says on the tin and nothing more or less, which with today's games is somewhat of a blessing as it has been a while since I've bought a game that did what is promised, I dislike the fact that when it comes to piecing together a jig-saw, Pixel Puzzler fails. The snap-to-grid action as opposed to fitting pieces together, coupled with the fact that with the weird shapes the piecing together is nothing but a 'find the weird shape that fits another weird shape affair', works to render the game alltogether too easy and robs the player of a challenge.

Still a fun game that provides a good diversion and most certainly not overpriced. But it fails where it matters and that's a shame.

The game is poorly coded and is not visually appealing, so the whole experience is really far from the tranquility and meditativeness it must supply. The music and sfx is really good, and the price is fitting (I'm talking, of course, about the offer of getting it for free), but even so the overall experience is not positive.

For small puzzles, this can be an entertaining enough time waster.  Unfortunately, the game has two major issues.

First, puzzles are easy.  There is no piece rotation, which makes it rather obvious where pieces will go.  The distance that you can be off when you place a piece is rather forgiving, making it easy to place pieces by guessing.

Second, the user interface is fatally flawed when playing larger puzzles, to a degree that large puzzles are exercises in frustration where you often simply cannot pick up the piece that you actually desire to pick up.  Unplaced pieces float in a pool around the board, and with large puzzles you have large clumps of numerous pieces.  The fatal flaw is that piece selection does not appear to be based on what the screen shows, and it appears to be nearly (if not entirely) impossible to pick up certain pieces if others are nearby.  One would think that the game would grab the top piece under the cursor, but it often doesn't.  Not only will it often refuse to grab the top piece of an overlapping stack, sometimes it appears to vacuum in nearby pieces that aren't even under the cursor.  You can know exactly which piece you want to pick up, but find it impossible to actually get the game to pick it up.

Introduction: Pixel Puzzles: Japan is a casual game in which you solve a variety of jigsaw puzzles by clicking and dragging a puzzle piece from the river surrounding the board to where it belongs on the board itself. While the game does several things correctly, it ultimately has too many problems for me to truly recommend it. It is a decent game, but falls just short of greatness.



Gameplay:  Being a jigsaw puzzle game, there is only a certain amount of gameplay to be expected. You solve the jigsaw puzzles by clicking on a puzzle piece from a flowing river around the edge of the board to the board itself. It's simple; however there are a few annoyances.

The river constantly moves the puzzle pieces around, which is quite neat for the smaller puzzles. However, the puzzle pieces bounce off each other and the edges of the river. This results in puzzle pieces being clumped together on the larger puzzles, even getting stuck in corners. In one such puzzle, there were about seven puzzle pieces stuck in a corner, overlapping each other.

Picking the puzzle piece you want in this mess is an annoyance as the click detection seems a bit off. Despite my mouse being directly over the desired puzzle piece, I would often pick up the puzzle piece just beside it, over and over. Even though I knew the piece I wanted, I struggled against the game to actually get it. Dropping a puzzle piece back in the river spawns it to the bottom left part of the river instead of the spot you dropped it, which further adds to the clumping" issue.

For the small puzzles

I like doing puzzles because they encourage me to focus. I intently study the pieces to find commonalities in colours and shapes. This game, however, has the puzzle pieces constantly floating around. This makes deliberation very unpleasantly laborious, and you have to fish for the pieces you want. I guess that's supposed to be a challenge, but I think a challenge has to be something much more than annoying the player: I know which piece I want, I know where I wanna put it, but I can't grab it.

Every correctly identified piece clicks into its place, after which you cannot move it again. This means that you can mindlessly move a piece around, and after a few clicks, you can just randomly put it into place. On top of this, you cannot lock two connecting pieces unless one is already in its place on the board. I believe a system like the one in Braid (not even a jigsaw puzzle game) woulde've been much better: You should be able to lock pieces anywhere, and then find a place for them on the board together.

The game has a level system, and it's mindbogglingly misguided. It's really unappealing to have to blindly click through quite a few 60-piece low level puzzles to get to better and more challenging ones. (I'm assuming higher level puzzles are much more fun, despite the floating pieces issue.)

The puzzle images are nice, but the UI is really rudimentary and ugly.

This game could be acceptable as a mobile game just to pass the time when you're on the bus, but on Steam, it's just at the bottom of the pile.

The game is poorly coded and is not visually appealing, so the whole experience is really far from the tranquility and meditativeness it must supply. The music and sfx is really good, and the price is fitting (I'm talking, of course, about the offer of getting it for free), but even so the overall experience is not positive.

So... What to say about 'Pixel Puzzles: Japan'... It's a puzzle game! No rotating blocks... No floating pills... No exploading candies, gems or animals... But an actual jigsaw puzzle game. Now if it were just that, my review would be done now, but there's more. The puzzles are lovely and are in various shapes, cuts and sizes.\nThe goal of the game is simple... Complete a puzzle and obtain a golden puzzle piece for your monk so that he may ascend to a higher state... and ultimately, puzzles with more pieces. As you set about the task putting together the puzzles, the pieces not on the board yet, float around on the surface of a pond and you have to try and scoop up the piece you'd like. If you toss a piece back into the water, you can sink a number of pieces foor a moment in hopes of making it easier to grab the piece you do want... And that's it.\nIt's a nice, simple and relaxing game, set to soothing oriental music; perfect for the casual gamer that enjoys a slow paced game or the hardcore garmer looking to find that calm before the storm of bullets and rampaging zombies... among other things.

Althought I like puzzles and puzzle games, I cannot recommend this game based on two glaring issues.

-No save feature: this is the big one. Not being able to save means you're stuck working on a puzzle or leaving it running in the background unless you want to start completely over.

-Piece selection: 9 times out of 10, clicking on piece you need will make you pick up a different piece that is floating around near it. It's frustrating to say the least, and the later puzzles (200+ pieces) are almost impossible to finish without the stacking exploit because of this failure to point and click.

If you're an achievement hunter, the 26 achievements aren't hard to earn, just very, very tedious. The game also drops 6 cards, but the are almost worthless on the market due to the free keys for this game given away recently.

If a save feature was implemented and the piece selection fixed, I would recommend this game; until that time, save your money and your hours for something else. I haven't played anything else in the series so I do not know how they compare.

It's all fun and games at the beginning and you wonder how is it even possible to screw up on a simple game like this. The puzzles are easy, not too many pieces, but then you get to the last ones and the flaws become apparent. You can't save your progress in the middle of a puzzle, you can't join pieces together out of the board, and, the worst of all, you can't get the piece you want because it's burrowed under thousands of others you don't want, and because every piece just decides to float wherever they want, there is no way to dig them out in time.\n\nAlso, if you manage to stack every single piece, you always get them in the correct order from the top left to bottom right, so nice programming.

Honestly I purchased this game for the trading cards and because it was on fabulous Steam sale for 69 cents.  I am a fan of real-life jigsaw puzzles, but this is not my normal computer game choice.  I rationalized it by telling myself the wife would enjoy it.

In order to get my card drops I played the game, and I am not on puzzle 6 or 7.  The interface is incredibly simple and refined to just what is necessary to play.  The one annoying issue, which has already been lamented in many of the other reviews is the piece selection.  It seems to have an issue with the Z-order and collision rectangles of the pieces when they are in close proximity.  You will click on one piece but the game will select another.

That is the only complaint I have with this love little relaxation inducing game.  For 69 cents you really cannot go wrong by adding this to your collection.

Plays like a school programming project. Design flaws and frustrating mechanics are at odds with the peaceful theme, plus you can't save your progress and your settings seem to reset every time you close the game. Thousands of better puzzle games out there
