It's a ZEN world

Pixel Puzzles lets you put pieces on a board until they form a picture, but fails to deliver a worthwhile jigsaw experience. Why? Well, two reasons, mostly.

Firstly, the game doesn't care if you find two connecting pieces and put them together, which is how I (and most people) usually go about completing a jigsaw. Instead, it only cares if you put a piece in it's correct position on the picture, because yes, I absolutely knew that random piece went in that exact spot when it's closest neighbours are 6 pieces away.

Secondly, while I actually like the little pond with pieces floating around, constantly shuffling, the fact that 9 times out of 10, I can't just click on the piece I want and actually get it, rather than another piece floating in the area, is extremely frustrating.

Due to these two glaring design flaws, I cannot recommend this game. I'm sure there are some people who will be satisfied with it, but I'm also sure there are far better alternatives out there.
This is probably the most creative interface I've seen for a jigsaw game on PC or mobile

A nice diversion, but really not anything special. It's just jigsaw puzzles. And a few of the pictures don't really make for good jigsaw puzzles either, images being too homogenous. There's also no save feature which is... yeah, not great. And it's a bit of a pain to pull out the piece you want, especially on later puzzles where there are a lot of pieces. It's not really an authetic jigsaw experience either since pieces snap into place when they're close to where they need to be, but you can't put pieces together if you find, say, two center pieces that aren't connected to any edge pieces. It's easy to cheat the system and it forces a specific progression otherwise, which is a bit of a problem when you can't actually pull out the edge pieces you need because it keeps pulling up the wrong piece. There's not anything else to it except jigsaw puzzles, despite what the game's page says about interactivity. I got this free in a bundle, and yeah, that's about what it's worth. A good time-killer and mildly enjoyable but you could prooobably do better.

Jigsaw puzzles are supposed to be relaxing and enjoyable.  This game is neither.  It's like someone tried to implement every poor design decision they could come up with, to see how much frustration they could stir up.

- Can't save a puzzle, have to complete the entire puzzle in one sitting.
- For some reason, the pieces float around the border of the puzzle, and when there are hundreds..........
- Mouse detection is horrible, if you actually pick up a piece you were aiming for it's a small miracle.
- Pieces ONLY snap together when put in their proper place.  No way to connect a few pieces and find their home later.

This is one of the most frustrating games I've ever played, it's almost like some psychological test to see the boundaries of sanity.
The benefits of a virtual puzzle are offset by ever-moving pieces and poor click detection. Fix those, and it's worth the purchase.

While the game is extremely fun to play, it is really bad.

Developers made almost no effort to deliver a good product, there are 2 hugely bad things about this game: the piece fishing" system and the audio (both music and effects)

I really do like this game, but it has some major bugs.

Out of the 14 puzzles I have completed, I've had to restart three when I only had one piece left to place. I had to restart twice due to the final piece not fitting correctly. One needed to be rotated and the second time the piece shape needed to be flipped (the negative size needed to be on the right and the positive side needed to be on the left). The third time, there wasn't a final piece, the game somehow made one piece just disappear. I grabbed the fish a million times to try and see it if was stuck, searched the river and corners, I clicked all over the completed puzzle to make sure it wasn't just hidden on the board, but alas, it was nowhere.

I also find it to be frustrating when trying to grab a specific piece and it grabs every single piece other than the one I have selected. I usually get around this by only selecting pieces that are on the top since they are not as crowded.

I cannot recommend this to anyone who is a completionist, like me, due to the fact that sometimes you cant complete the puzzle unless you restart. I still purchased this despite a review saying they didn't recommend this, but it was less than a dollar. However, once I experienced these bugs, I found myself wondering how in the world something could be so badly designed that pieces dont fit/ are missing.

Either way, I think this is a great idea and it is relaxing (until you experience said bugs). I just wish they would fix the bugs and then it will be a great, simple, and cheap game.

reviewText: great game for the win

Honestly I purchased this game for the trading cards and because it was on fabulous Steam sale for 69 cents.  I am a fan of real-life jigsaw puzzles, but this is not my normal computer game choice.  I rationalized it by telling myself the wife would enjoy it.

In order to get my card drops I played the game, and I am not on puzzle 6 or 7.  The interface is incredibly simple and refined to just what is necessary to play.  The one annoying issue, which has already been lamented in many of the other reviews is the piece selection.  It seems to have an issue with the Z-order and collision rectangles of the pieces when they are in close proximity.  You will click on one piece but the game will select another.

That is the only complaint I have with this love little relaxation inducing game.  For 69 cents you really cannot go wrong by adding this to your collection.

Plays like a school programming project. Design flaws and frustrating mechanics are at odds with the peaceful theme, plus you can't save your progress and your settings seem to reset every time you close the game. Thousands of better puzzle games out there

It's a good game, with a relaxing music, even if it's nothing more than a classic puzzle. I just wish it was possible to save the progression of a puzzle, because the bigger ones are a bit long to complete in one run.

Pixel Puzzles: Japan is a jigsaw puzzle game that is delivered on Steam and works on Windows.  That's the good.  You can finish puzzles.  That's good too.  Now for the bad:
1. Lack of realism: having pieces constantly moving about in a pond is a terrible idea.  You don't get time to really look at any particular piece, and it's near impossible to pick up the piece you want.  It's easy to pick up a piece, just not the piece you want.  And if you drop the piece you don't want and it's near the piece you want, the piece you want dissapears, perhaps showing up later somewhere else.  This is not just a bad idea for enjoyment of game, it's bad in that it makes my eyes hurt after a while.  It's like trying to catch a small fish with a large net in a pond that's crowded with many other fish, and all fish are swimming about randomly and at high speed.
2. Short lived.  There's 21 puzzles using five difficulty levels.  No, that doesn't mean 21x5=105 combinations, as particular puzzles (pictures) has a preset difficulty which can't be changed.  When finished these, there's nothing more to do, except perhaps do the same again.  You gotta be kidding.
3. The essential challenge of solving a jigsaw puzzle has been eroded.  You can solve any puzzle without even looking at each piece, simply by test-dropping each piece at random places on the canvas.  The tolerance level is high, and so at least in the lower difficulty levels, if you place a piece on the canvas for the purpose of taking out of the dreaded pond, there's a good chance that you'll place it close enough to where it's supposed to go and that it will instantly and permanently click into the correct spot, even if it's the first piece to do so and even if it's near centre of canvas.  Good game design not only means allowing intended solutions, it should also include preventing unintended solutions, particularly when they don't add to the fun.

If you want a decent jigsaw puzzle game, I'm afraid at the moment you may have to look beyond Steam.  I've purchased Jigsaw Puzzle Platinum Edition" by "RealOne Arcade" for $20 (above game was $7) and it's allowed me to feel okay with offering the above critical review.  It's hard to criticize when there isn't anything better available.  If I had my time over
recommended: knowing that there's nothing in :Japan that I'd miss.\n\n"

reviewText: A game that you use to kill time (and get trading cards to sell)

A surprisingly nice way to pass the time and take a break from all your action, MMO, FPS, RPG, rogue-like, dungeon-crawler what-have-yous. The atmosphere, music, and puzzles are quite immersive and the go-at-your-own-pace (non-timed) element makes this great for young and old alike.

That said, there are some obvious flaws within Pixel Puzzles - Japan:

There is no mid-level save feature. This is the biggest issue that can easily flip a recommendation. The beginning levels are easy enough to sit through in one sitting, taking anywhere between 5-20 minutes each (or more if you're really taking your time). Once the puzzles get harder (and the amount of pieces start increasing), the probability of you wanting to take a break will shoot up. Your only options for taking a breather will be either to 1. Tab out of the game and leave it running until you want to come back to it or 2. Close out of the game and restart the entire level. Both options are pains in their own ways.

Puzzle-fishing can sometimes be more annoying than the puzzle itself. Puzzle pieces float around in a pond that borders your puzzle mat (it's actually a zen garden -- fitting). There is no pause feature for the pond so you're left trying to grab the piece you want in the middle of all the others. Clicking or click-hold-releasing a piece over the pond will make it poof and teleport somewhere else in the water. When you've been clearing out a pile and you accidentally clear out the piece you want as well.. it's a little frustrating. It's easily avoidable if you're not a dolt like me.

Possible catch-release bug? Not quite sure if it's my laptop/touchpad/mouse but it sometimes takes me a couple of clicks to pick up pieces. Some of them get stuck" on the board (when they're not in the right place) and takes several tries to grab. I'm running Windows 8.1 in case the problem's on my end.

Cons taken into consideration
date: I would still recommend this game if gifted or purchased on a discount. I don't think the retail price is worth dealing with the snags that may make you want to rage-quit (or completely abandon the game) but it's a good little single-player casual to fiddle around with."

This is a pretty good game.  It took 7.8 hours to complete the entire game (19 puzzles) and get all the achievements.  There is nothing wrong with the game technically and it works perfectly.  The pictures that make up the puzzle are great.  There is a lot of variety in puzzle cuts.

The only negatives are the music and grabbing the pieces in the river during larger puzzles.  The music is redundant so I turned it off and listened to the radio instead.  The game has all of the puzzle pieces floating in a river above and to the left of the puzzle area.  When it gets crowded with a lot of pieces in the more difficult, larger puzzles at the end of the game, you very rarely grab the piece you are clicking on.  Gets annoying and adds more time to the puzzle.  Also, when you grab a piece and don't need it and drop it back in the river it doesn't land where you put it and just disappears and gets mixed up with the rest of the pieces again (so you can't set a piece to the side for later).

If you like jigsaw puzzles you'll like this game and for the price you can't go wrong.
I like this game. Very good to relax.

A perfect little game to play while waiting for a download to finish or something like that. A nice theme, some pretty challenging puzzles later on, but there are just too many small annoyances that make you think: 'why didn't the developers fix this? They surely must have played their own game?'

These are the things that make a possibly calming game into an occasional teeth grinder:

Puzzles can't be saved mid-game. So when you have been playing Pixel Puzzles while waiting for something to finish downloading you can't save your current state of the puzzle. This destroys the whole casual nature of the game. It's either finish the puzzle or start the puzzle over the next time. And with pretty masive puzzles in later levels, that's just not cool.
The puzzle pieces literally float around a fish pond that surround half the puzzle field. In later levels the amount of pieces increases. This also makes the puzzles pieces very, very small. It becomes quite hard to see them and properly discern them from one another. And to add to the problems with this...
The mouse pointer is incredibly inaccurate. Imagine wanting to click-drag a puzzle piece from the pond onto the table, and having to click six or seven times, because the pointer keeps picking up pieces besides the one you want. Oh, and remember that the pieces float around? Yeah, terribly annoying.
The sound is supposed to add to the meditative, monastery-like atmosphere of the game. Too bad the sound quality is pretty low and several sound effects have a slight static to them when they play.
For €6,99 there's just too many obvious things unnecessarily working against the player. Around €2 would be acceptable and I then would also recommend the game, because the puzzles are challenging and have a pretty big 'just one more puzzle before bed' feel about them.

For small puzzles, this can be an entertaining enough time waster.  Unfortunately, the game has two major issues.

First, puzzles are easy.  There is no piece rotation, which makes it rather obvious where pieces will go.  The distance that you can be off when you place a piece is rather forgiving, making it easy to place pieces by guessing.

Second, the user interface is fatally flawed when playing larger puzzles, to a degree that large puzzles are exercises in frustration where you often simply cannot pick up the piece that you actually desire to pick up.  Unplaced pieces float in a pool around the board, and with large puzzles you have large clumps of numerous pieces.  The fatal flaw is that piece selection does not appear to be based on what the screen shows, and it appears to be nearly (if not entirely) impossible to pick up certain pieces if others are nearby.  One would think that the game would grab the top piece under the cursor, but it often doesn't.  Not only will it often refuse to grab the top piece of an overlapping stack, sometimes it appears to vacuum in nearby pieces that aren't even under the cursor.  You can know exactly which piece you want to pick up, but find it impossible to actually get the game to pick it up.

Introduction: Pixel Puzzles: Japan is a casual game in which you solve a variety of jigsaw puzzles by clicking and dragging a puzzle piece from the river surrounding the board to where it belongs on the board itself. While the game does several things correctly, it ultimately has too many problems for me to truly recommend it. It is a decent game, but falls just short of greatness.



Gameplay:  Being a jigsaw puzzle game, there is only a certain amount of gameplay to be expected. You solve the jigsaw puzzles by clicking on a puzzle piece from a flowing river around the edge of the board to the board itself. It's simple; however there are a few annoyances.

The river constantly moves the puzzle pieces around, which is quite neat for the smaller puzzles. However, the puzzle pieces bounce off each other and the edges of the river. This results in puzzle pieces being clumped together on the larger puzzles, even getting stuck in corners. In one such puzzle, there were about seven puzzle pieces stuck in a corner, overlapping each other.

Picking the puzzle piece you want in this mess is an annoyance as the click detection seems a bit off. Despite my mouse being directly over the desired puzzle piece, I would often pick up the puzzle piece just beside it, over and over. Even though I knew the piece I wanted, I struggled against the game to actually get it. Dropping a puzzle piece back in the river spawns it to the bottom left part of the river instead of the spot you dropped it, which further adds to the clumping" issue.

For the small puzzles

TL;DRFor the people that don't like reading walls of texts.

WHAT IT IS:A traditional Jigsaw Puzzle Game with a theme that's all about Japan.

GENERAL RECOMMENDATION:
NO. It's not a bad game per se (I personally enjoyed it) but it has a lot of flaws that makes it hard for me to recommend it to everyone. I still would recommend this game for jigsaw puzzle enthusiasts but, preferably, only when it's on sale.

RECOMMENDED FOR:	Those who love solving traditional jigsaw puzzles.
Those looking for a relaxing casual video game.
Those who like or appreciate Japan and its culture.
Those who have the time and patience to complete puzzles.
NOT RECOMMENDED FOR:	Those who don't like solving puzzles of any sorts.
Those who couldn't care less about Japan and its culture. You'll be looking at pictures from Japan for hours so you have to be appreciative of it otherwise it might bore you.
Those looking for an adrenaline pumping game. Unless you find solving jigsaw puzzles to be intense...
Those who don't have the time and patience to complete puzzles. It doesn't save your progress while you're in the middle of solving puzzles. You can read more about it on the rest of the review.
THE REST OF THE REVIEWFor the people that actually like reading walls of texts.

SAVE THE WORST FOR FIRST
I remember a long time ago when I used to piece together jigsaw puzzles of different sizes. I remember how I'd feel really good about myself each time I complete a puzzle and I get to show it off to the rest of the household. I also remember not being able to complete some puzzles in one sitting. I'd piece together parts of the puzzle and when I get bored or have something else to do, I just leave it as is until I can come back to finish it.

That last part is important. Some jigsaw puzzles take time to complete (depending on the size) and not everyone has the time to finish a puzzle in a single sitting. The ability to save progress in the middle of piecing together a puzzle is present in physical jigsaw puzzles. But sadly, it's a feature that's absent  in this game. And it is, in my opinion, the game's biggest flaw.

YOU CAN'T SAVE IN THE MIDDLE OF PIECING TOGETHER A PUZZLE.

I'm not sure why such an important feature is absent from this game. The first couple of puzzles only took me about 10-20 minutes to solve so it didn't bother me at the start. But as the puzzles start getting larger and more difficult, it easily became more apparent that this game needed a save feature. The last couple of puzzles could take more than an hour (if not hours) to complete and not being able to save your progress until you've actually finished solving the puzzle was really frustrating.

Note: The devs seem to have learned from this mistake and made sure that you can save progress in their latest Pixel Puzzles games. But sadly, they seem to have no plans (or they're not able) to patch in a save feature for this game in particular. So, it's beyond...SAVING (bad pun intended).

WHO DOESN'T LIKE JAPAN?
I like Japan. The land of anime, manga, vending machines, sushi and other weird yet oddly delicious food, among all other things. It's probably the number one in my list of countries I want to visit one day.

The game's focus is on the traditional Japanese setting which might seem boring to those who are not interested at all about the country. If you're not into Japan and it's culture, then you probably won't like the game. But if you're like me who can appreciate the beautiful pictures of traditional Japanese locations and such, then you'll probably enjoy this game.

SOME WEIRD GAME MECHANICS
Some of the jigsaw pieces in the later stages of the game take on really weird shapes. It makes the game a lot harder but also interesting and somewhat fresh.  This is a positive.

The player also gains a 'power-up' of sorts after piecing together a certain amount of puzzle pieces into the board. What this power-up does is show the entire picture for about 5 seconds. Now, that would've been neat but I feel like 5 seconds is too short especially in the later puzzles of the game considering that getting the power-up itself is no easy task. So in all honesty, I feel like the power-up is not really all that helpful.

The puzzle pieces that have yet to be properly placed into the board float in the pond and keep moving around. It's very clunky and unnecessary. The pieces don't stop moving while floating in the pond and it makes it hard for the player to pick up a specific piece. Try to imagine solving a physical jigsaw puzzle. Now, imagine that all the puzzle pieces that have yet to be properly placed on the board keep moving around. It makes the game harder than it should be and it does get very annoying.

RELAX, IT'S JUST A GAME
Jigsaw puzzles are relaxing brainteasers. Sure, puzzles tend to be frustrating at times to finish, but you have all the time in the world so you can solve puzzles at your own pace. This game is no different. It's made for relaxation. The pictures and the peaceful ambient music help support this.

Sadly, there are some negatives about this. One is the save feature which I've already explained. It could've been a much more relaxing game if you didn't have to worry about losing your progress while piecing together a puzzle.

And the second one is the music. It's relaxing. Maybe a little too relaxing. Relaxing to the point where you just feel like taking a nap instead of finishing a puzzle. I had to play my own music in the background just to keep myself awake while solving the puzzles. This would not have been a problem if only it had a save feature where you can just quit the game, take a nap, and finish it at a later time.

(Again with the save feature...it's like being able to save your progress is the missing piece of the puzzle that would've made this game much better.)

CONCLUSION
As a traditional jigsaw puzzle game, it's good. You have a variety of puzzles to solve and they even take on different wacky shapes later on in the game. But it's plagued with flaws; most notably a lack of a mid-game save feature which made me decide to give it a Not Recommended" review. If it's on sale and you're into jigsaw puzzles
date: then maybe you should pick it up.\n\nThe devs have also learned their lesson and included a mid-game save feature on their latest Pixel Puzzles games which is great. But until the same feature is implemented to this game in particular
recommended:
my "Not Recommended" rating still stands.

REVIEWER'S CREDIBILITY
Solved all the puzzles. Got all the Steam achievements.[i.imgur.com]"

The game is fun until you get to the highest levels. Then it becomes extremely annoying.  The puzzle pieces you want become impossible to grab from the pool of the unused ones - I had to click like ten times until I got the one I wanted (I think this is a bug - they sort of float around, moving constantly, passing over each other, but even though the one I wanted was on the top, clicking on the pile kept giving me the bottom ones that I didn't want... and by the time I got through the pile, others floated over the one I wanted again. EXTREMELY annoying.)

Overall, the game has nice environment, a few jokes incorporated into it, not-so-special pictures as puzzles (I didn't find the photographies used particularly beautiful - they look like snapshots a tourist might take when visiting Japan), and no option to save your unfinished work.

Overall, I'd give it about 45% - it could have been worse, but there are better games to spend money on out there.

Relaxing game, and reminds me of my childhood. Pictures are quite nice, and game is great for those who like puzzles.\n\nThe only downside is there is no save option, which is needed when you are doing some of the harder puzzles.

I really do like this game, but it has some major bugs.

Out of the 14 puzzles I have completed, I've had to restart three when I only had one piece left to place. I had to restart twice due to the final piece not fitting correctly. One needed to be rotated and the second time the piece shape needed to be flipped (the negative size needed to be on the right and the positive side needed to be on the left). The third time, there wasn't a final piece, the game somehow made one piece just disappear. I grabbed the fish a million times to try and see it if was stuck, searched the river and corners, I clicked all over the completed puzzle to make sure it wasn't just hidden on the board, but alas, it was nowhere.

I also find it to be frustrating when trying to grab a specific piece and it grabs every single piece other than the one I have selected. I usually get around this by only selecting pieces that are on the top since they are not as crowded.

I cannot recommend this to anyone who is a completionist, like me, due to the fact that sometimes you cant complete the puzzle unless you restart. I still purchased this despite a review saying they didn't recommend this, but it was less than a dollar. However, once I experienced these bugs, I found myself wondering how in the world something could be so badly designed that pieces dont fit/ are missing.

Either way, I think this is a great idea and it is relaxing (until you experience said bugs). I just wish they would fix the bugs and then it will be a great, simple, and cheap game.

Pictures are nice, dificulty is descent, but the selection of pieces is just horrible... you see the piece you need, you click to pick it up but instead you get the one that is blelow it... and you keep clicking and discarding until there is only one left and then you click the wrong button and it's gone -.- very frustrating still i managed to solve all the puzles in under 8 hours.\nall in all a descent puzle game just not worth 7 eu :)

This is a pretty good game.  It took 7.8 hours to complete the entire game (19 puzzles) and get all the achievements.  There is nothing wrong with the game technically and it works perfectly.  The pictures that make up the puzzle are great.  There is a lot of variety in puzzle cuts.

The only negatives are the music and grabbing the pieces in the river during larger puzzles.  The music is redundant so I turned it off and listened to the radio instead.  The game has all of the puzzle pieces floating in a river above and to the left of the puzzle area.  When it gets crowded with a lot of pieces in the more difficult, larger puzzles at the end of the game, you very rarely grab the piece you are clicking on.  Gets annoying and adds more time to the puzzle.  Also, when you grab a piece and don't need it and drop it back in the river it doesn't land where you put it and just disappears and gets mixed up with the rest of the pieces again (so you can't set a piece to the side for later).

If you like jigsaw puzzles you'll like this game and for the price you can't go wrong.

I picked up Pixel Puzzles: Japan as it looked fun, but mostly because it looked like a nice game to relax and chill out with.

The game itself is alright, the mechanics work adequately, though can be a little annoying when retrieving pieces from the jigsaw pools.

The problem I had with the game, however, is that the audio quality used in the game for the sound effects and background sounds and music were very low quality and were peaking heavily, which hurt my ears after a while, and eventually caused me to exit the game.

If you want a nice jigsaw game, I'd recommend it, as it works fine for what it is, however, you may wish to lower the volume.

reviewText: So authentic that you can almost smell the mothballs emanating from grandad 's rustic cardigan as he sits next to you with wise advice on how to solve the 19 puzzles.\n\nThis is the caramel flavoured boiled sweet of PC gaming.
Such a good game!

This game is a pretty straightforward collection of 21 jigsaw puzzles, with each puzzle depicting a different Japanese landmark.

19 of the puzzles are structured into unlockable tiers:
Tier 1 Initiate" = six 60-piece puzzles
hoursPlayed: \nTier 4 "Scholar" = three 220-piece puzzles
voteText:
and Tier 5 "The All Knowing One" = one 350-piece puzzle.

You start off the game with access to only the easiest group of puzzles
helpfulPercent: and must complete every challenge in that bracket to unlock the next set of difficulty.\n\nIn addition to these tiered sets
votesHelpful: there are also two separate bonus puzzles
votesTotal: available at any time from the golden section of the selection screen. They are in line with the higher difficulty settings
votesFunny: one because of its high piece count
commentsCount: and the other because of its unusual piece shapes.\n\nThat's one thing I really like about this game
column16: it plays with the overall shape of the pieces and with the interlocking edges. While there are a few puzzles that utilize the traditional silhouette
column17: most of them mix it up with non-uniform sizing and unique key designs (spirals
column18: arrows
column19: prongs
column20: pinking sheared
column21: jagged scallops
column22: etc).\n\nAs far as the puzzle gameplay is concerned
column23: the format is simple. You start out with a blank "sand garden" space where you build your puzzle
column24: surrounded by an L-shaped koi pond that houses your unused pieces. You then use your mouse to pick up pieces from the pond and move them around the game board. When a piece is dropped close enough to the correct placement
column25: a sound effect with play and it will snap into place.\n\nOverall
column26: the game is as basic as it gets. You can change the colour of the sand
column27: you can adjust the volume of the music
column28: and you can switch between fullscreen and windowed
column29: but beyond that there isn't any additional functionality:\n\n- You can't save your progress mid-puzzle. If you exit a puzzle screen
column30: either to the main menu or to the desktop
column31: you forfeit any work you have done so far (completed puzzles stay completed
column32: however).\n- You can't turn off the water feature. The unused pieces in the koi pond are constantly floating
column35: and the pieces that appear on top of the pile are not always the ones that will be picked up by your mouse. This is not really a problem when you are dealing with 60 pieces
column36: but on the harder difficulties you will spend half of your time trying to fruitlessly and frustratingly fish out the pieces you want from the pond.\n- There is no zoom mode. The board size remains the same regardless of piece count
column37:
so on the higher difficulty tiers it gets harder and harder to see the edges of the pieces.
- You are unable to consult even a thumbnail of the image you are working on during a puzzle.
- You can't build sections of the puzzle independently and then move those sections into place.
- The 21 puzzles are always the same on every playthrough.

While you are puzzling
column38: you are entertained by occasional snippets of music. There are a handful of motifs programmed into the game
column39: each one no more than 10-30 seconds long
column40: and each one sounding like the introduction to a song rather than a complete melody. Sometimes you will hear a refrain and then 1-2 minutes of silence. Sometimes the game will play a medley of snippets back-to-back. Sometimes the game will play the same snippet back-to-back. It's possible that the music is somehow tied-in to what actions you are doing
column41: but I couldn't discern any predictable pattern or rationale. Honestly
column44: and in-line with the cultural aesthetic of the game
column46: and the inconsistency of how they were played
column47: was distracting and annoying. (What the music thought it sounded like: "Nostalgic touches of music
column49: falling on your ears like leaves falling from trees..." What the music actually sounded like: "A child haltingly and repetitively trying to learn shamisen in the apartment next door.")\n\nThere are 26 achievements for the game
column50: which basically boil down to "play all the puzzles and mess with the fish." You will automatically unlock 99% of them in one playthrough.\n\nTL;DR - If you are just looking for a casual and basic jigsaw game with a good number of puzzles
column52: and featuring postcard-quality images from Japan
column53: then this is 100% the game for you. However
column54: if you are looking for a high-challenge
column60: then this is simply not going to meet your expectations. For what it is
column61: and what it claims to be
column62: it does a pretty decent job.\n\nI received this game for free as part of a bundle
column63: and got 11 hours of mostly-fun gameplay out of it. I would give it a 7/10."

reviewText:
Well, it is a jigsaw game and it is actually pretty good at what it stands.
It does have some problems, though. The music can be pretty repetitive and instead of relaxing it can actually make you pretty sick of it after some time playing the game (You can turn it off, of course, so it's not that great of a problem). It is also pretty hard to see the pieces when they're flowing along the river (where all the to-play pieces are at), since it is smaller and they get one over the other.
Also, when you pick a piece, it usually picks not the piece that you're aiming at, but instead another random piece (after some thoughts, I think it actually picks the piece that goes closer at the top of the puzzle, although it actually changed with some puzzles).

But if you like jigsaw puzzles it can be fun for a while. Also, you can leave the game open and return to it from time to time, like a real jigsaw.
I enjoyed playing this puzzle and finally I've got all puzzle and achievement. Thanks for Pixel Puzzles: Japan
Came for the achievements , stayed for fishing puzzle pieces !!!\n

This game explain itself as its a jigsaw puzzle so my review will consentrate on other issues. I hadnt made a jigsaw puzzle since childhood and ill guess its 25 years ago since i did one of this magnitude (200-300 puzzles) and i bought this one with the intent of a bit of a casual gaming and to get the achievements.
First of all when doing jigsaw puzzles its common to arrange the puzzles in some order before really getting started to get a good overview of the colours and for that sake the puzzles themselfs. In this game the puzzles starts floating around in a pond and its difficult to get that sort of overview as the only place you can do that is in the field where the puzzle is laid. So the player has the choice to have a messy area where the puzzle is put together or grabbing the moving puzzles in the pond where they keep moving over and under eachother and it gets pretty random which one you get.
The mechanics of this game is like when you move the puzzle and you get to the place where its supposed to be it locks onto the spot without the option to remove it again so its quite easy in that way. As i mentioned earlier in this review i partially if not mainly bought this game to get the achievements but it seems this games achievments are pretty broken atleast to some degree as ive gotten two involving picking up a koi fish and another one regarding the same fish. Ive played the first 6 tables (i believe it was 6) and solved them all and even done  one or two of them twice but i still havent got a single of the puzzle achievements so im pretty infuriated to have wasted my time on this game.
In the end if you like puzzles ill recommend doing a real one because of the before mentioned issues of this game and for myself ill guess i wont do another jigzaw puzzle for the next 25 years and it certainly wont be this one.

reviewText: Anime was a mistake. - Emperor Hirohito
um?

So... What to say about 'Pixel Puzzles: Japan'... It's a puzzle game! No rotating blocks... No floating pills... No exploading candies, gems or animals... But an actual jigsaw puzzle game. Now if it were just that, my review would be done now, but there's more. The puzzles are lovely and are in various shapes, cuts and sizes.\nThe goal of the game is simple... Complete a puzzle and obtain a golden puzzle piece for your monk so that he may ascend to a higher state... and ultimately, puzzles with more pieces. As you set about the task putting together the puzzles, the pieces not on the board yet, float around on the surface of a pond and you have to try and scoop up the piece you'd like. If you toss a piece back into the water, you can sink a number of pieces foor a moment in hopes of making it easier to grab the piece you do want... And that's it.\nIt's a nice, simple and relaxing game, set to soothing oriental music; perfect for the casual gamer that enjoys a slow paced game or the hardcore garmer looking to find that calm before the storm of bullets and rampaging zombies... among other things.

Althought I like puzzles and puzzle games, I cannot recommend this game based on two glaring issues.

-No save feature: this is the big one. Not being able to save means you're stuck working on a puzzle or leaving it running in the background unless you want to start completely over.

-Piece selection: 9 times out of 10, clicking on piece you need will make you pick up a different piece that is floating around near it. It's frustrating to say the least, and the later puzzles (200+ pieces) are almost impossible to finish without the stacking exploit because of this failure to point and click.

If you're an achievement hunter, the 26 achievements aren't hard to earn, just very, very tedious. The game also drops 6 cards, but the are almost worthless on the market due to the free keys for this game given away recently.

If a save feature was implemented and the piece selection fixed, I would recommend this game; until that time, save your money and your hours for something else. I haven't played anything else in the series so I do not know how they compare.

It's all fun and games at the beginning and you wonder how is it even possible to screw up on a simple game like this. The puzzles are easy, not too many pieces, but then you get to the last ones and the flaws become apparent. You can't save your progress in the middle of a puzzle, you can't join pieces together out of the board, and, the worst of all, you can't get the piece you want because it's burrowed under thousands of others you don't want, and because every piece just decides to float wherever they want, there is no way to dig them out in time.\n\nAlso, if you manage to stack every single piece, you always get them in the correct order from the top left to bottom right, so nice programming.
If relaxing and doing a puzzle from time to time sounds enjoyable then this is for you.\nAchievement hunters will also like this one as it is easy to get 100% on.

With all the games that are out there, I am surprised there's not more PUZZLE" games like this. This REALLY IS a puzzle game. A game where you actually put pieces of a picture together so you can form a whole picture.\n\nThe game starts out with big
date: simple pieces so you can solve the puzzles easily
recommended: as well as help you get started with how the game is played. As you move on to the next level
hoursPlayed:
the pieces get smaller as well as having to deal with more pieces at one time.

My only real complaint is that you can't put pieces together to make a whole piece and then try to place that whole piece in the spot it belongs. You have to "know" where each piece goes on the board. So the point is you have to find where the piece goes on the board without being able to make clusters of pieces.

Overall a very good idea for people who are into "puzzle" games. Think about it
helpfulPercent: you get  40 puzzle boards to complete. Each board you pass gets harder to solve because the pieces get smaller. Versus getting a "REAL" puzzle
votesHelpful: you can't lose pieces
votesTotal: and you can't lose the game."

I recommend this game for relaxing puzzle sessions (I

reviewText: Recently I was extremely bored and looking for games in my massive steam library to get 100% achievements on. I ran across Pixel Puzzles: Japan which I picked up from some bundle offer at one point and installed it. My girlfriend came home from work and I asked her to play a video game with me, which is at times very hard to get her to do. She agreed and I decided to fire up this game, as she is quite the puzzle-holic and loves jigsaw puzzles. After hours of playtime, we got all of the achievements in the game and had a good time doing it.\n\nPixel Puzzles: Japan is basically a set of normal jigsaw puzzles on PC. There are 19 different puzzles in the game, which get incrementally larger the farther you go. Putting together the puzzles is fairly simple and works well overall. One large annoyance we experienced consistently is attempting to grab a piece from the pond"

After about 7 hours and a half in this game I think I can write a proper review for it. It has both bad and good things but it's not unplayable, despite it's flaws.



At first it was really fun, but as you play more and more you start to observe the problems with this game. And they are annoying:

1°) Lack of a save feature (last puzzle has 350 pieces and it took me about an hour to complete). If you are not patient enough, this game is not for you. You could Alt+Tab the game and do something else as a break from the puzzle, but I wouldn't do that to much (in the past I had some problems with some games on steam where I couldn't Alt+Tab because that would break the game).

2°) The music is kind of nice, but it becames repetitive quite fast. You could try to mute it, but that would mute all sounds of the game and there is a little click sound when you place a piece in the right place which I found quite useful.

3°) The images are nice, but have too many similar colors and aren't in HiRes. As the puzzles had more and more pieces it became quite hard to find the exact place where one piece would fit. It's even harder if you have a small screen (I played mine on a laptop and it was very painful and it placed a lot of strain on my eyes). The fact that it doesn't show you a big picture of what the puzzle should look like it doesn't help at all. It does have a little hint" thing where it shows you the picture for a few seconds
date: but it puts the pieces over the actual picture and when you have many correct pieces it became even harder to find where you should put the other pieces (you can move the pieces normal when this "hint" it's activated). The "hint" button is charged at random when you place pieces correctly; you need 8 charges and you can get them all in a row or you can place 20 pieces and won't gain a single charge.\n\n4°) Picking the piece that you want from the pond can be really hard. Due to a glitch (or bad programming)
recommended: if yhere are 2 consecutive pieces overlapped
hoursPlayed: it will ALWAYS give you the first piece (the left one) regardless of which is on top. This can actually help you to solve the puzzles (it is explained in guides how to do it)
voteText:
but it aomewhat kills the fun of doing a puzzle.



It has some good parts too:

1°) It has a decent variety of piece shapes
helpfulPercent: but sometimes this can be annoying.\n\n2°) The pieces are always oriented the right way (you can't rotate the pieces). It the beginning it may seem boring
votesHelpful:
but later on you will be grateful that you don't need to rotate the pieces.

3°) You won't lose any of the pieces like you would with a classic jigsaw puzzle if you are not careful.

4°) Achievements are not hard. 24 of the you will get just by finishing all puzzles. You also have to catch the fish which is moving around in the water (you will probably do this by mistake) and you must the fish in the Shishi-odoshi (I think that's what it's called that water thingy at the bottom left corner).



Overall it's not a very bad game
votesTotal: but it's not worth 7 €/$. If you can get it in a bundle or on a sale (at least 66%) then you should give it a try (if you like jigsaw puzzles of course)."

[I'm only about 1/2 through so far, playing on a casual basis from time to time]

A not-so-quickly completed puzzle game based on the classic board game puzzle pieces; featuring a variety of shapes and sizes with increasing difficulty.

# Relaxing Music, although the occasional sound of the Sōzu can get irritating after a while!
# Increasing difficulty and changing shapes really adds to the difficulty and the desire to continue playing
# Well chosen imagery depicting various aspects of Japan in a more traditional sense
# ...Here fishy fishy!

Aside from the minor annoyance with the Sōzu already mentioned above I would say the only improvements I could offer would be for MORE puzzles. If there is more of them later - then great! Otherwise a random mode would be great to see for replayability. Randomise the amount of pieces based on a chosen difficulty, then pick different imagery and shape/size of pieces.

The only downside is its price. $7 can get you a lot more than just puzzles; it can get you an RPG or a cheap shooter.
I got the game free as part of an offer, but can definitely recommend during bundled sales.

Who knew solving jigsaw puzzles could lead to total enlightenment, well, at least it does for the monk in the game ~

There are 19 puzzles to solve, and all of them are Japanese landscapes, which are very beautiful.

The difficulty rises as you unlock more puzzles. Basically, after you've played a few of them, the number of pieces will increase.

The music is relaxing, though it loops a lot, and does not vary much, which I thought was a little disappointing.

My biggest problem with the game is the mechanic to pick up a piece. Sometimes, my mouse will pick up the wrong piece and it will take several tries for it to finally detect the one I wanted.

In addition, you can't save the game while doing the jigsaw puzzle, so you better not close it if you don't want to lose your progress.

It is a relaxing and just a fine casual game to kill some time. But some parts of it are frustrating.

Despite some nice features, I will not recommend the game, unless you get it at a decent price or from a bundle.

My reason being that picking up pieces was very annoying >_< especially at the end of the game, when there was a lot of pieces in the water. It made the game less fun...it also strained my eyes =_=;

~ Hope this review was helpful.

It certainly hasn't made me want to throw out all my real jigsaw puzzles, but for what I paid for it, it's a fun distraction.

Pros:
-I like the music and sound of the game. It's very minimalist and zen, very traditionally Japanese. It's nicely relaxing for a game like this.
-The images are all Japan related, so if you like that kind of thing, you'll like these.
-The level up" aspect is sort of neat
date:
levelling up your little monk to do harder and harder puzzles.

Cons:

recommended: not where you dropped it.\n-Pieces can't be put together on their own
hoursPlayed: they have to be dropped into their space on the board. So you can't put together a section separately and then move it into the main board when you can. voteText: which spoils it a little bit.\n-The pieces are all always right side up. You don't have to rotate them or anything like that.\n-The pieces aren't 'standard' puzzle shapes

What I thought would be a relaxing pass-time, is actually the most unintuitive jigsaw puzzle simulator game I've ever played. Almost everything about this game goes against everything I've ever known about putting together puzzles.

For instance, y'know when you get two seperate pieces that fit together? I'm not sure about you, but my first instinct would be to fit them together. Unfortunatley, the way the game works, is that each individual piece can only snap into place once it's directly where it needs to be in the picture. So instead of being able to put the puzzle together peice by piece, you're forced to leave all the pieces you need scattered on the board, which brings me to the next biggest problem of the game: The koi pond.

Surrounding the top left corners of the board is a koi pond where all of the peices of the puzzle reside. While being an interesting idea in theory, turned out to be this games biggest negative aspect. Again, lets think about how a real-life jigsaw puzzle works. When you're looking around at the countless peices you have to choose from, seeing which colors might match what you're trying to fit in, wouldn't it be great if all of those peices were constantly floating around in a sporadic, aimless fashion making it extremely frustrating to take the peice you want? No. No, that isn't great in the slightest.

That isn't even the least of the koi pond issues. More often than not, you'll end up grabbing a piece you didn't mean to pick up, so you'll put it back down in the pond. Where does that peice go, you ask?  It reappears in a random spot in the pond. While this might not seem like that big of an issue, when you're trying to get the peice you need as it meshes in with all the other peices in the pond, if you pick it up and drop it accidentally it flys to a completely different location, further wasting your time. Not to mention there is a koi fish in the pond that you're able to pick up, which will often get in your way of picking up the pieces you want.

This game just seems like a whole new species of headache inducing terror, which is a real shame because I really do enjoy the Japanese theme it was introducing, and I really do feel like it could have been great if they reworked those problems. There just needs to be another jigsaw puzzle game like the one from OMGpop.com a few years ago, it was a flawless jigsaw puzzle game that really embodied the experience of putting together a puzzle with your friends. But until then, I guess I'll have to check out Pixel Puzzles: Anime. God help me.

First off, I love jigsaw puzzles, so it always interests me when there's a jigsaw puzzle title so I can see what kind of gimmicks they put into the software. In this one, you have all the pieces floating around randomly in the water and when you put enough specific pieces in place, you can get a brief preview of what the finished image is supposed to be.

For most of the puzzles, this is all fine and dandy. However, when you get to the last few puzzles that are over 200 pieces, trying to find that piece that you're looking for floating in that mess is quite annoying. And then, I don't know how, but somehow the computer knows what piece you're going after and gives you every other piece BUT the one you're going after. It'll even give you a piece that's not where you're clicking, only near it.

Another thing that I didn't care for in this title is the method that the pieces snap into place. On this one, the pieces snap to the board. I much prefer that the pieces snap to each other since it makes it easier to see if you got any pieces laying around on the board when you're wondering what the hell you did with the last few pieces.

One thing I really did like about this was the interesting ways the pieces were cut. It made the puzzles seem more unique and fun.

It took me about 13 hours to go through all of this. My overall rating lands just on the not recommended side.
This is such a peaceful, simple game to play, I love it. The music and sounds are also very calm and peaceful. A very nice game to play if you just need quiet time to clear your head.

Fun litte game, but beware of mouse arm and annoyance. Higher levels will still pool all your pieces and you'll spend an extra hour just trying to get the right piece. Kind of forces you to change playstyle and just pick up the edges and work from there by color. The pieces are moving so when you got +200 of them, you'll usually not get the piece you want at the first try. I got the game as a gift. However I wouldn't say it is worth €7 as listed today at 8th December 2015. Wait for a sale and pick it up for half or less if you're into puzzle games.

I think it's the first pixel puzzle, and it shows, It's easier than the later ones.
The pieces are already in the correct position so you don't need to rotate them.
The pictures are nice, but sometimes a bit blurry.

The biggest culprit, the 220 puzzles are a nightmare to do, you try to pick a piece from the pond (when there are still a lot of pieces) and it's always the wrong piece.. Reading the forums, this has been a bug for a long time and has never been fixed (that's really bad as it should have never even be this crap)... But as another user says, the easiest is with these 220 puzzles, to not drive you insane, is to just put the wrong piece on a pile on the edge of the board and dump them later back into the pond..
Mind you this only seems to happen with the 220 puzzles, all the others don't really seem to have this problem.

Another minor point is the two extra 220 puzzles above and below the 350 one, if you finished them, they stay greyed out..

I bought this when it was on sale for 1.40 euro, and I think that's a good price, but I can't recommend it full price due to the annoying bug (and the fact the developers haven't fixed it even though they have released a couple of other pixel puzzles after that one).

Nice puzzle game with beautiful pictures of Japan. The only annoying thing is picking the right pieces from the stream in later levels. Also, very easy to get all achievements if you're aiming for complete games.
As a puzzle-lover I loved this game. It's beautiful, not too easy (on higher levels) and not too hard. Great game to put your mind off for an hour or so.

The hardest part about this game is not finding the right place for each puzzle part but to pick the desired parts up.
Lose pieces floating around the puzzle might look good - but it takes forever to find that specific part you want to pick up because there are others floating over it and when you push the other parts away (this is possible) you also push the part you wanted to pick up away.

If you do not have enough time to solve the entire puzzle and have some real life duties... bad luck. You cannot save while you're in the middle of your puzzle. Progress lost.

If you find two or more pieces which belong together: you cannot stick them together unless you know the right place on the picture.

The puzzles are fine, but the game is not. There are too many faults with this game for me to recommend it to anyone.

You cannot save your progress if you want to close the game. Puzzles always start from the beginning. It is easy to reset a puzzle, because the game does not ask you for confirmation before resetting a puzzle.

Puzzle pieces which haven't been kept on the board yet keep moving around needlessly, which is okay for puzzles with big pieces, i.e. not a feature that improves the game, but not one which makes it frustrating either. However, if you try playing a puzzle with tiny pieces, you will repeatedly pick up pieces that you do not want to use, and as soon as you drop a piece back, it disappears under your mouse, and reappears somewhere else on the 'pond' around the puzzle board. I've had sessions where I picked up 10-15 wrong pieces in a row because the correct one was flowing under a ton of wrong pieces, and then I was so in the flow of picking and dropping wrong pieces that I picked up and dropped back the piece I wanted to use, which then immediately disappeared and went to some other part of the pond, getting lost in the flood of pieces moving around, not to be found again anytime soon.

You can't fit puzzle pieces together even if you know that they will eventually end up next to each other. The only way to snap two puzzle pieces together is to put both of them in their correct spots on the board. So, the game makes it hard to work on multiple parts of the puzzle at the same time, unless you can figure out exactly where in the board those parts will fit.

Overall: Stay away. This is at best a bad and often frustrating implementation of what is supposed to be a relaxing table top activity.

A decent puzzle building game. I love doing puzzles but this one just seemed to bore me after getting through about 10 of them. I didn't like that you had to complete each puzzle in one sitting. You can't put half the puzzle together and save the rest for later. It will reset the puzzle if you go back to main menu. I can really only recommend this if you like some ok pictures of Japan  and really love puzzles to the extreme.

Nice puzzle game. My 3 year old son that the koi was hilarious, especially when it swims across the screen if you take it out of the water. The graphics were nice. However, there is no saving, auto or manual. So, expect to sit down and either complete it in one go or have it running in the background while you do other things. If you exit before you completed all the puzzles, you'll have to restart in your Achievement quest.\n\nI would recommend this game, although I have been told the other Pixel Puzzles are better. I'd try to catch this one on sale since the nonexistant saving gets REALLY frustrating (especially when you want to take a break and play a different game!)
Doing jigsaw puzzles on your computer is really relaxing.

This game is pretty decent, it can be nice and relaxing but whoever programmed the piece-grabbing ♥♥♥♥ the bed. You can literally spend minutes fighting with the game trying to grab the right piece because they float around in a pond. It is a nightmare.

Oh my word the design choices on this one. Sounds fun and mellow enough, just a classic fit the pieces together puzzle like your grandpa did on the table top. Your grandpa could always look at the box to see the picture, but I still can't seem to figure out how I made the picture pop up that one time. Then there are the absolutely tiny puzzle pieces floating in a pond. Floating all over each other, and generally being a nuisance to click, or find the one piece you want. I've had to click 10 times, randomly getting other nearby pieces, before finally getting the one I want. The pictures themselves are pretty, but several just don't have enough definition between areas of the puzzle. It turns them into a random does this fit here?" mess of trial and error. Then I haven't found a way to save in the middle of a puzzle

Product received for free\n\nThis is a beautifully themed variant of pixel puzzles. It is exactly what it promises to be. The music is relaxing to have in the background whilst attempting to complete the puzzles. The tiered levels do get fairly hard and time consuming( the pieces get smaller and more numerous). My only complaint is not having a save feature to allow you to complete the puzzles in stages. A great game to pass some time if you enjoy jigsaw puzzles.
Good game, if you like puzzle games get it.
